THE SUN LOW IN THE SKY

dialogues.speaker: THE CREDITS
dialogues.text: Which are SUPERIMPOSED OVER a SCENE of almost unnatural beauty. A thickly wooded forest which practically shut ou the sunlight. All is not serene however. SHOTS RING Out - and we are privy to a running battle between a German pat and a band of Russian soldiers. It is a desperate fight - and several bodies fall. we see the faces of several men whose identity we will learn later. The shooting is still going on when the CREDITS come to an END. Then --

dialogues.speaker: THE SLOPE OF A HILL
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is MOVING SLOWLY up the hill. The verdancy of the hill, the intermittent clusters of daisies and dandel are evidence of the season -- late Spring. Now the crest the hill is in sight; above it a patch of blue sky is visible. The mood is pastoral, peaceful. The CAMERA reaches the crest -- and suddenly a pair of hi polished boots almost fills the SCREEN. The CAMERA comes to an abrupt HALT. Then SLOWLY, the CAMERA PANS UP from t boots to take in a carefully tailored German officer's un and then the face of the German officer -- CAPTAIN STRANS It is a longish face with a high forehead and light blue eyes. It is a face that gives an impression of extreme forcefulness, an impression underlined by the thin - lipp mouth and angular chin. His hair is white at the temples, emphasizing by contrast the healthy tan of his face. At the moment, Captain Stransky is gazing through a stere telescope. His expression is grim. Behind the Captain stands LIEUTENANT MEYER, a youngish, good-natured face.  However, it is apparent from his expression that he has no great liking for his Captain. His lips are tight as the Captain moves the knobs of the telescope with long th fingers. Captain Stransky straightens up, locks back at Lieutenant Meyer, whose expression quickly changes to one of impassivity. Stransky, whose demeanor is angry, says nothing, but turns to peer again through the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW THROUGH TELESCOPE WHAT CAPTAIN STRANSKY SEES
dialogues.text: A patch of woods, about a square mile in area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stransky straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (angrily) Incredible -- sheer stupidity. Those woods should have been cut down or destroyed by fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, but we retreated too hastily for any such luxury.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I disagree. It was an irreparable oversight, and I shall send a report to that effect to Regiment. (looks at the woods, reaches for cigarette case ) Do you think the Russians are already in those woods? (offers Meyer a cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: MEYER
dialogues.text: Thank you. We'II know soon enough. Corporal Steiner is on a recconnai sance patrol.  Stransky drops his cigarette butt, steps on it.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Reconnaissance patrols have a way of not returning.

dialogues.speaker: MEYER
dialogues.text: Steiner will be back.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (angrily) I did not ask your opinion Herr Meyer. Meyer says nothing. We can see that he regrets his impu dence. With a mixture of anxiety and curiosity, he waits to see what will happen next. The ANGLE WIDENS to TAKE IN a PRIVATE who walks up to the Captain, salutes.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE
dialogues.text: Captain Stransky? Lieutenant Colonel Brandt Would like to see you at headquarters. Stransky nods, gazes sharply at Meyer, walks off, the CAMERA TRUCKING with him. All about him are SCENES of great activity. MEN are digging bunkers and preparing positions. SHOUTS fill the air. As Stransky passes, he is greeted by salutes which he acknowledges with the briefest of nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An armed GUARD is on duty. He salutes smartly as .Captain Stransky comes INTO SCENE, returns the salute without looking at the Guard, ENTERS the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: are examining a map that hangs on the wall. The older of the two is LIEUTENANT COLONEL BRANDT. About fiftytwo,  a gaunt gray face. The younger officer is a CAPTAIN. In his middle thirties, a tired expression, but his features are intelligent. At the moment, he is Shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: If our main line of resistance is at Novorssysk, What are We doing do@@nhere?

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (shrugging) We're playing fire department.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Several hundred miles from the heart of the fire? Does that make sense? The door opens and a CORPORAL announces:

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: Captain Stransky.  Stransky APPEARS on the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Come in, Captain. You know my adjutant, of course.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Of course. How are you, Captain Kiesel?

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: Awful. Terrible. How are you? Brandt laughs, Places a bottle of wine on the table.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: This might cheer you up, Kiesel. Stransky inspects the label.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: My respects, Colonel Brandt. Producing a 1937 Moselle in the  southernmost corner of Russia.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (fills glasses) A bottle of Moselle is no more absurd in this region than We ourselves. Your health, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: I am not going to drink to my health. My health is terrible and doesn't deserve to be drunk to. (holds up his glass) To the end of the damn war.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Incidentally, Colonel, why does our presence in the bridgehead strike you as so absurd?  Brandt looks at Kiesel, then turns to Stransky.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (ignoring the question) Captain, Why did you ask to be trans ferred from France?

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (laughs) Exactly what my commanding officer in France asked me. I can't stop you, he Said, Since I'm convinced that without you the eastern front would collapse in a matter of days. Go ahead, you heroic fathead.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: (quickly)  I withdraw my toast to the end of the war. To heroic fatheads everywhere. Stransky doesn't know quite how to take this, but decides on a faint, icy smile.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Captain Stransky, is there any news on Steiner?

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: No, sir, not yet. Brandt shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Incidentally, What sort is he, Steiner? Kiesel looks at Stransky closely.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: A problem....no respect, but a first rate soldier so one looks the Other Way. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (a short laugh) Of course, I've only been on this front a few days, matter of hours actually, but I see -- rather I sense -- a sort of -- well, it's not exactly insubordination -- Well, let's call it -- a lack of respect.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: If I hope into a cab which gets into an accident because the brakes fail, I blame the driver, not the  company he works for. I'll say that he should have refused to drive a cab with defective brakes.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I know What you mean by that.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: (looks at him a moment, then easily) I don't intend to discuss polities.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (angry) You talk avout lack of respect -- low morale..... it goes hand in hand with impending defeat.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Defeat? I refuse to admit that possibility.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: (dryly) We'll, said, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I don't believe that the German soldier --

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: The German soldier! (laughs mirthlessly) In the early years they saw the retreating backs of the Russians too often to be frightened by his face now. The replacements, on the other hand, think every Russian  is an infallible fighting machine. I feel damn sorry for our poor land sers.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (frigidly) In the present state of our nation, such talk borders on treason. I am a soldier and as such it is my duty to subordinate my own ideas to the interests of my country.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: (Smiles easily as he lifts glass) We are still doing our duty, Captain Stransky. Stransky, his face white, glares at Kiesel.  The PHONE has been RINGING. Brandt picks it up with a Snap.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Yes? -- What? -- Good, Meyer. Wonderful. What sort of shape are they in? -- I see. (hangs up) Lieutenant Meyer. Steiner is back.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Naturally, I'd like to talk to him. I intend to promote him to Senior Sergeant on the spot.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: (wryly)  Most generous of you.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (saluting) If you'll excuse me. Brandt nods. Stransky LEAVES. There is a moment's silence

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Well, what do you think of our Captain?

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: (a moment's thought) Must have the most expensive tailor in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: And, of course, he won't rest until he gets the Iron Cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toasts) Gets...... not earns? Brandt, who has lifted the wine bottle, finds it empty.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Oh, to hell with Stransky and the Iron Cross. And you, too, Kiesel. They smile at each other grimply.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT MEYER
dialogues.text: Pacing back and forth in a trench, outside of a bunker door. Occasionally he steals a glance at a group of men who are slumped in various indolent positions on the floo of the trench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS SLOWLY from face to face. There are nine men in the group (all will be identified later indi visually). At the moment, all look exhausted, dirty and somewhat disgusted. The men, with the exception of two, PASTERNACK and ANSELM, are in the same age range (about 25 to 30). Pasternack and Anselm are younger. SCHNUR BART is distinguished by a heavy beard. KRUGER by a tough weather beaten visage. DORN has the look of an intellectual. STEINER'S extreme gauntness is what catches the eyes. His face is expressionless. The others, MAAG, HOLLERBACH and KERN are nondescript, runofthemill faces. Meyer walks past the men in silence. They do not pay too much attention to him. Several are smoking cigarettes. Meyer looks toward the bunker. The CAMERA, following his gaze, MOVES TOWARD the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is seated at the table. He is a very young, very handsome officer. An orderly. KEPPLER, is busy at a hot plate with a coffee pot. He, too, is very young. After a moment --

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Is it very hot? Captain Stransky won't stand for anything but hot coffee.

dialogues.speaker: KEPPLER
dialogues.text: It is practically scalding, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: KEPPLER
dialogues.text: Is there anything else you wish, sir?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Not at the moment. As Keppler starts out:

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Just a minute. You can keep me company for awhile. I really hardly know you. Sit down some where. Keppler looks around uncertainly. Triebig is sitting in t one and only chair.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Sit on the bed. Are you always so timid?

dialogues.speaker: KEPPLER
dialogues.text: (with a shaky Smile) No. He perches on the extreme edge of the narrow bed. Triebig  studies him. Keppler's habitual expression is one of helplessness, accentuated by a mouth he keeps permanently slightly open.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Where do you come from?

dialogues.speaker: KEPPLER
dialogues.text: Frankfurt, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Is that so? I know Frankfurt quite well. (sits on the cot beside Keppler) If you get along with me, you'll have a good life here. You may go now. Come to my bunker tonight and arrange my gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping enthusiastically to his feet) Yes, sir. When shall I come, sir?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Don't come too early. Around ten. We'll have a chance to talk. Do your best and I'm sure I shall be satisfied with you. Keppler salutes and GOES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Triebig COMES OUT. The men are watching Keppler as he WALKS OFF.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: Not a very robust type, would you say?

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (the youngest of the group) Well, Schnurrbart, you're so excessively masculine, it evens things up. The CAMERA PANS to Triebig. He seems to sense what the me are thinking. A bit disconcerted, he turns to Meyer.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (sardonically) Do you think we can get them to Stand at attention when the Captain gets here?

dialogues.speaker: MEYER
dialogues.text: (grins)  I don't know, Lieutenant. I'll put it up to them, man to man. There is some half hearted laughter from the men. Steiner is noticeably quiet.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: I'm not getting up till they want my Signature On the Peace Treaty. But he gees someone approaching, and slowly he starts to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: approaching the trench. In the b.g. the men CAN BE SEEN reluctantly getting to their feet. Triebig snaps to atten as Stransky comes in.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (a Smart salute) Captain. Stransky, barely nodding to Triebig, looks over the men, discernible expression on his face. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Which one is Corporal Steiner? Steiner takes a step forward, slackly comes to attention. Stransky studies him -- disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: You are Corporal Steiner?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (almost nonchalantly) Yes, sir. (pause) I am Corporal Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I had formed a -- somewhat different picture of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unconcern in his face) I'm sorry if I disappoint the Captain. In the b.g. several of the men permit themselves slight smiles, which fade immediately at a glance from Triebig. Stransky looks at Steiner again.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (loudly) You are promoted to Senior Sergeant, promotion to be effective at once. He watches Steiner's face. It is as if he had spoken to a tree. There is no surprise in Steiner's face; only a slight flexing of his arms indicates that he has heard at all.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: You heard me, Corporal -- Sergeant Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Your promotion doesn't seem to have made much impression upon you.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: No, sir. There is an involuntary giggle from young Anselm. Stransk glares and there is silence.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (to Lieutenants Meyer and Triebig) Come in -- you, too, Sergeant. He starts down the steps to his bunker, Meyer, Triebig  and Steiner following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is seated behind a table. Steiner, Meyer and Triebig, slightly to the side of him, stand facing Stransky, who has taken out an elaborate cigarette case. He extends it to Meyer who takes a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MEYER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Captain. Stransky offers a cigarette to Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: No, thank you, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (lighting his cigarette) After what you've been through, you don't feel the need of a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No at this particular moment -- sir.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I'm ready for your report. He reaches into pocket, lays sheaf of crushed papers on t table. Stransky looks at him in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I'd like to hear the gist of your report.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Lots of Russians. Lots of guns. (grimly) We should be hearing from them very soon.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: What about your platoon -- any casualties?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Two killed. One missing.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Two killed. How?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (dryly) Bullets.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (flushing angrily) I deduced that. That missing man -- did you look for him, Steiner?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (shrugs impatiently) We had no time to lose. It would  have been irresponsible to risk the safety of the entire platoon for the sake of one man.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: There ought not to be a missing man in Such a case.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (no expression) Sorry, sir. I'll try to do better next time.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (grimly; after a moment) I have the feeling, Sergeant, that you somewhat overestimate your importance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes darken; but no change in voice) At the moment, I am free of any such illusions. The two men look at each other; then Stransky's eyes fall on the tommy gun Steiner holds in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: That's not a German gun.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: No, sir It's all in the report. We surprised a Russian platoon -- and when they ran, they left their guns.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Oh, captured material. Good.  Where is your gun?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: We couldn't carry both, so we left ours.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: What! You left your guns for the Russians!

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes, sir. Our guns for the Russians.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: That I cannot understand. You must be aware that the quality of our arms is far superior to that of the Russians and -- He stops as Steiner shakes his head. Stransky raises his  eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: ...the Russian guns are better!

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (sharply) That is stupid, loose talk. You have every reason to be grateful for the fine equipment the Father land puts into your hands at the cost of countless sacrifices.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (cannot suppress a mirthless grin) I never asked then to put the stuff  in my hands, Meyer looks toward heaven. Stransky takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: MEYER
dialogues.text: (hastily) sir, Sergeant Steiner is greatly in need of sleep. I'm positive that When he -- Stransky cuts him short by turning his back in a gesture dismissal. Meyer motions for Steiner to follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: jump to their feet as they see Steiner and Meyer.

dialogues.speaker: MEYER
dialogues.text: Be careful he's taken strong dislike to you.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (wryly) Too bad. I'm crazy about him.

dialogues.speaker: MEYER
dialogues.text: He can be trouble...

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (laconically) I've survived many a battalion commander. I'll survive Stransky, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at his desk, coffee cup in hand, sipping.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Dammit. This coffee is cold.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir. It was heated not too long ago  There is a LOUD EXPLOSION as a shell lands nearby. The near miss has shaken up the bunker. Lieutenant Triebi is righting a table that has overturned. Captain Stransky girm faced, is dusting off his uniform.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (placing some papers on the table; feeble smile) Too close for comfort, I should say, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: How many more papers are there for me to sign?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Quite a few, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (sitting down; crossly) Let me have the junk. As he glances through the papers and signs his name. Trie watches him with his soft eyes, the smile remaining fixed on his face. As Stransky finishes signing he looks up, sniffs the air, looks at Triebig rather strangely.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: That isn't perfume I smell -- is it?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Oh, no, Captain -- (apologetically Just a bit of after shave lotion. It -- bucks me up.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I see. He fixes his gaze upon Triebig whose smile fades under the  scrutiny. Then, Stransky's manner changes suddenly. He gestures toward a chair, tries to inject a cordial note into his voice.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (offering him a cigarette) Where were you stationed before you joined the battalion?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (voice softening) In the south of France -- Bordeaux.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Ah! Then being transferred must have come hare, eh? (voice casual) Why were you transferred anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment's Silence) I voluntarily applied for a transfer, sir.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) How interesting. There is mounting apprehension in Triebig's face as Stran regards him fixedly. Then again there is a sudden change Stransky's expression. Again it becomes friendly -- to Tr great relief.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: We lived in real mansions right On the beach. Swimming at any hour, day or night. It was indescribable  -- the sea, the palms, the beaches, the people, everything -- Overwhelmed by his memories, he stops. Stransky is surpri to see him swallow with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (a knowing smile; winks) The women, you mean.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (raising his head@j I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I said, the women. I mean -- in referring to the people -- you meant, of course, the women?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Not so much that. I am -- that is-- (suddenly confused I didn't have much time to think about women. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (casually) Do you like soldiering?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (emphatically) Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (nods patronizingly) I'm glad to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: It's like living in an altogether different world. The Candle hag burned down. Stransky rises to light anoth

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: It is indeed a very different world. A world of danger and a world of men, a world without women. (laughs; puffs, gets thoughtful) men can get along without women. I tell you, man's truly natural destiny is not to breed children, but to be free, to rule and fight -- in other words, to lead a man's existence.... women are no more than a fancy,  a superfluous dessert. (blows a smoke ring; looks at Triebig) Or do you disagree? Triebig looks at Stransky in some confusion. What is Stra getting at. Then he gets a grip on himself. Intertwining his fingers, he regards his thumb thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: I don't think I disagree, sir. (after some hesitation) I think that if I have to I Can live without women.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I'm pleased to hear that. He studies the burning tip of his cigarette; then looks u  quickly.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: In other words, you prefer the company of a man to that of a woman?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (greatly troubled now) It depends on the situation.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Really? Stransky smiles. Triebig does not reply.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: If it will help you, I will put your thoughts into words for you. (smilebroadens) You prefer the society of men to  that of women in any and all situations. The words hang in the silence of the bunker. Triebig re- treats into himself like a snail sealing itself up in its shell. He stares with mingled fear, assent and hope at Stransky's face which still registers nothing but friendl assent. Then, afraid silence might be interpreted as agreement, he murmurs...

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: I -- don't understand, sir --

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (smiles confidentially) Let's drop the hide and seek. By God, Triebig, you don't have to put up a front with me of all people. What I said is true,  isn't it? Say yes, man, for heaven's sake.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (with the air of a man wanting to stop himself; in a bare whisper) Yes. Stransky springs to his feet, directly in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Speak up! You said yes. You said yes. didn't you? Don't you dare lie to my face. At the sight of Stransky's enraged face, only a few inche from his own, Triebig closes his eyes in horror. Stransky shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feebly) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (releasing him; stepping back) Stand up! Trembling, Triebig obeys. Slowly, and down.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I can assure you of this! If I catch you trying any of that stuff, I'll have you hanged, remember that! Before all the men! Do you understand that? Do you hear me? Stransky looks him up  Triebig is unable to answer.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Now get the hell out of here and keep out of my sight for the next twenty-four hours. You turn my stomach. Triebig stands immobile.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Get out! For a second Triebig looks at Stransky's distorted face. Then he wheels around, stumbles across the threshold I en VANISHES. Stransky remains in the same spot for a moment, then he fishes for a cigarette, smiles. He is satisfied with the picture of the complete military, masculine imag he has presented.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVETO
dialogues.text: Steiner walking watching men digging in, goes into Brandt's bunker after looking up at the sky for a long mo

dialogues.speaker: BUNKER COL. BRANDT
dialogues.text: The door opens and Steiner COMES IN. The scowl leaves Brandt's face. He strides forward to meet Steiner; presses his hand vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: So here are you -- unpunctual and unsoldierly as ever. He laughs and propels Steiner toward a chair.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (laughs) I read your report. It's enormously valuable. I intend to transmit it personally to the General -- Ah,  one thing. Captain Stransky has sent in an official complaint about the guns. What have you to say to that?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (stolidly) What can I Say? I threw away German guns to make room for Russian guns.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: The Russian guns are better. I know it. You know it. The men know it. Captain Stransky seems somewhat in the dark. Brandt looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fresh bastard, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Brandt looks at Steiner and crumples Stransky's report. H offers Steiner a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Last month I offered to pull you out of the line and give you a staff post?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir --- and I remember refusing.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: ....something about your feeling of solidarity with your men. Well --  I renew the offer. I want you on my staff. No answer from Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: All right -- what's the reason for refusing this time?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (after a moment) I don't want to be dependent on anyone -- not even a regimental commander.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: As usual, I find it hard to under- stand you.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (dryly)  I'm sorry to hear that. A good sgt. should be completely under- stood by his superior officer.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Steiner! Are you laughing at me? (getting up) Steiner stands up and looks expectantly at Brandt, whose mouth twitches.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (voice shaking) Get out! Steiner half salutes and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in machine gun emplacement. Darkness has fallen. Maag is looking out into the night. Suddenly, a Russian sub-  machine gun OPENS UP. head in the dirt. Maag, frightened, tries to bury his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walking in the darkness. At the BURST of BULLETS, he has dropped to one knee. Now, there is silence again, and Steiner peers cautiously into the darkness. There is ANOTHER BURST of FIRE ground. Then there is quickly and bounds to -- bumping into Maag, BURST of BULLETS.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (shouting to be heard) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: MAAG
dialogues.text: and Steiner stretches out flat on the silence again. Steiner gets up the nearest machine gun emplacement who is trying to get out. Another  (stammering) To -- get reinforcements.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (angrily) Leaving your post for that? He pushes Maag back into the hole. They huddle together t the Russian machine guns are quiet. Then Steiner peers through the loophole. A few shells WHINE through the air, EXPLODE nearby.

dialogues.speaker: MAAG
dialogues.text: (gasping) They must be right in front of us. In the Shell holes down there. Behind them there is the SOUND of RUNNING FEET and Schnur dives into the emplacement. Behind him come Kruger and  Hollerbach, and Lieutenant Meyer.

dialogues.speaker: MEYER
dialogues.text: What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: The big craters on the slope are full of Russians. Meyer stands frowning for a few seconds, then:

dialogues.speaker: MEYER
dialogues.text: (to Steiner) Signal for a barrage. Kruger -- get the rest of the company. I'll inform the Commander. He hurries OUT. Steiner picks up the flare gun. Back bent, he LEAVES the emplacement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he reaches a position in the trench. He inserts the cartridges in the flare gun. He sends up a FLARE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILLUMINED by the FLARE. The dark shapes of the Russians a visible in the craters. Then there is darkness -- then on again the landscape is ILLUMINED. The dark shapes can be seen burrowing into the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is looking at his watch with bated breath. Then he smi grimly as a hollow roaring SOUNDS above his head. It swel rapidly to a mighty moan and a moment later comes the hea detonation. Steiner turns as he HEARS hasty FOOTSTEPS. He sees Meyer running past him toward the MG emplacement. Steiner follows.

dialogues.speaker: MG EMPLACEMENT
dialogues.text: as Steiner slides IN, followed by Meyer. The men of the  platoon are already assembled.

dialogues.speaker: MEYER
dialogues.text: Commander's order. The Second Platoon is to undertake a counter- attack at once. You are to occupy the craters and take as many prisoners as possible. Sergeant Steiner, you will command. How do you think to proceed?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (considersbriefly We'll attack from three sides. Kruger from the west, Schnurrbart from the east and I from the south. When the firing starts We'll need artillery support -- to keep the Russians pinned  down in the woods. I guess that's all.

dialogues.speaker: MEYER
dialogues.text: (nodding) Good in theory; let's hope it works out in practice.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (smiles grimly) It's too simple; it'll never work. All right -- First Platoon, down the trench till I step you. With bent backs, Anselm and Pasternack in the lead, the m start down the trench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as with bent backs and faces taut with tension they proce down the trench. The CLATTER of weapons persists. The men stop, look at each other -- some with frightened

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (With a nervous laugh) Sergeant -- could I go make a telephone call? A titter, totally Without mirth, runs through the men.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (to Kruger) You and your boys stay here. Steiner raises his arm. The rest of the men follow him.

dialogues.speaker: SPOT FURTHER DOWN TRENCH
dialogues.text: as Steiner and the men come INTO VIEW. Steiner raises his hand in a signal to halt. Then he peers over the trench, lifts himself over, gives the signal for the men to follo

dialogues.speaker: SLOPE OF HILL
dialogues.text: We SEE the shadowy figures of Steiner and the men descen the slope. When they reach the level field Steiner again gives the signal to halt.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (to Schnurrbart) You wait here. Attack in exactly five minutes -- Schnurrbart looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: As soon as the first shots are fired, we'll come in. Clear?

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: (grunting) All Clear. He shakes hands with Steiner, who walks into the darkness followed by Kern, Anselm and Pasternack.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK
dialogues.text: trudging toward a clump of woods. Suddenly, Steiner drops to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER ON GROUND
dialogues.text: The other men have wordlessly followed his example. Ansel crawling on his belly, comes INTO THE SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (whispering) What's wrong? Steiner points his head leftward. Anselm follows his gaze

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moving cautiously through the darkness. They are no more than twenty yards away.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: Russkis! At least a hundred of  them! Steiner is hesitant.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: How many men has Schnurrbart got -- a dozen? They'll run right over them.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: Why don't we fire on them now?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: That may louse up the whole counter- attack. (bites his lips as he thinks hard) Schnurrbart probably won't even see them coming -- He reaches into his belt for flares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of flares -- and Schnurrbart can see he's getting visitors -- Then if we start shooting up their rear -- (shrugs) Maybe, the confusion -- He sends up two flares in quick succession.

dialogues.speaker: THE RUSSIAN COLUMN
dialogues.text: is taken by surprise. SHOTS RING OUT, several fall.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: All right -- after them. Stick close together and don't save on hand grenades. (ironically)  Remember, the eyes of the entire German nation are upon you. He runs in the direction of the Russians, the men followi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air is crackling with the SOUND of GUNFIRE and heavy EXPLOSIONS. Captain Stransky comes running OUT of the bunker, followed by Lieutenant Triebig. A Private comes running INTO the SCENE from the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE
dialogues.text: Word from Corporal Schnurrbart, sir. The Russians have broken into the trenches. Triebig looks alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (to Triebig) Take up positions in front of the  bunker with all the men attached to staff. I'll phone the combat train. He turns and runs hack INTO the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER AND ANSELM
dialogues.text: manning a machine gun. They are lying on the slope FIRING toward the trenches.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: We've mowing them down.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Who? Ours or theirs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the SOUND of faraway BURSTS of machine gun fire. Hollerbach and Kern are helping Anselm who is limping badly. Behind them are Dorn and Kruger. All look weary and begrimed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they come IN. (to Anselm) You're a damn fool not to go to the Field Hospital --

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (sinking to the floor) I'll wait until the holiday rush is over. Otherwise, they're just as likely to amputate as not.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLERBACH
dialogues.text: Does anybody still have any idea what the hell went on?

dialogues.speaker: DORN
dialogues.text: (who seems dazed)  --- confusion --- confusion --

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: I couldn't see anything. When something moved I fired at it. Probably got as many Germans as Russians.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLERBACH
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: Please -- a little respect for a wounded man. Steiner comes IN. He has a bandage on top of his head.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Kruger, what happened to you at the signal?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: I was Clearing Out the craters -- then I heard the firing from your direction --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I was wondering if you were waiting for a formal invitation.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: You know what you can do with your fuckin' sarcasm. I saved your ass.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Oh, did you? Well, you know what You can do with my --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Stransky and Triebig come IN. The men start to come to attention.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (curtly) At ease. (to Steiner) That was a bad business. You know half of 2nd Company was put out of action?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir. Our platoon was hit, too.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Why didn't the plan go according to schedule?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: We didn't think that --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: He is now close enough to the beach to stand. He takes an  uncertain step or two to stand, then he falls, his face down in the water. He makes no effort to rise -- allowing himself to slide deeper and deeper into the water. Sudden Gertrud's hands come INTO THE SCENE, grip Steiner's feet, pull him back.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD AND STEINER
dialogues.text: Struggling for breath, he lies on the ground. Steiner turns over on his back and looks at her. There is rage and shame on his face. The blood starts streaming do his face again. He tries to sit up. She tries to support him and he knocks her arm back.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: If you don't leave me alone I'll smash -- He stands up, takes a few steps to meet the incoming surf bends, scoops up a handful of water, washes the blood fro  his face. Then he turns and sees that Gertrud has retreated a few f up the beach, and stands watching him. The wind is blowin her skirt close to her thighs. He looks at her a moment, then, CAMERA TRUCKING with him, makes his way to her side. Gertrud looks at him steadily. Suddenly he seizes her. She struggles, wordlessly. Steine forces her to the ground. With one swift movement he pull her blouse from off one shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER AND GERTRUD
dialogues.text: She has stopped struggling. His face is close to hers. There is no resistance in her expression, but neither is there compliance. She looks steadily into his eyes as if there is a battle of wills. Roughly Steiner grabs her shoulders. Suddenly, he releases her, stands up. He watches her as she slowly sits up, rearranging her clothi  He stares at her without Speaking. Then --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) Why did you follow me? She doesn't answer. He shakes his head slightly.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Nurse Gertrud. keep your humanitarian paws off drunken men. It might be misunderstood.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: (breathing heavily You'reinsane.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (laughs harshly) We are all insane.  (he makes a tiny, mocking bow) goodnight. He walks toward the blackness of the garden. Gertrud turn to watch him until He is no longer in sight.

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: has just reached his bedroom door He is about to go in, when he stops, hesitates. Then he walks slowly to the nex door, leans forward, listening. He glances up and down th hall, then Slowly depresses the latch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A streak of LIGHT coming through a space afforded by the blowing curtains. As Steiner COMES IN, we SEE Inge's shap sitting up in bed.

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (Closing the door behind him) Three guesses. Inge, her long nightgown trailing around her ankles, him in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: Leave my room at once.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Out of character, but very nicely said. Don't worry; I just wanted to ask you if you have any aspirin. approaches Inge comes two steps Closer, looks at him. She hesitates. As she turns toward the door, he grips her shoulders and holds her tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you going to turn on the light?

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (feeling along her arms) You don't need any light, take my word for it. Pretending to struggle, she manipulates the nightgown off right shoulder, a maneuver not lost upon Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: Let me go. I'll scream. I will scream.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Naturally, you'll scream.  She closes her arms tight around his shoulders. When she tries to kiss him he turns his face aside. He picks her up and as he carries her toward the bed:

dialogues.speaker: SUNRISE
dialogues.text: framed in a window. CAMERA PULLS BACK to the interior of Inge's bedroom. Inge is lying in bed. Steiner is sitting on the edge of the bed, his back to Inge, looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Funny -- you boasted about your view of the sunset. I prefer the sunrise. Inge laughs. She sits up, throws her arms around his ches

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: You know -- never once last night did you say my name.  (strokes his chest) Don't you like my name?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Why shouldn't I like it?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Up to this moment I've never met a girl named Inge. At least not in bed. Inge laughs. When Steiner makes a move to get up, she hol him tighter.

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: Where are you going? He pulls himself loose, walks to where his shoes lying, picks then up. Inge, blanket up under her chin, watches h He turns.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: (angrily) Aren't you at least going to kiss me? He stoops and casually kisses her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Isn't it enough? Do you want to get paid? She starts up as though the pillow behind her had become hot iron. Then she throws herself face down on the bed, begins to sob wildly. Steiner stands for a moment, looking at her in embarrassment and some remorse.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (sadly)  Depend on me to say a few words to many. He walks slowly to the door, closes it behind him. 74. DELETED.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: who has just COME IN and is talking to a MAN at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: He sinks back into his seat, looks off at Gertrud. Then he rises and, CAMERA TRUCKING with him, winds his way across the floor to her. Her back is to him.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (quietly) Gertrud -- She turns, flushes as she sees him, but doesn't say a wor

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I wish -- I were meeting you for  the first time now.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: (looks at him) I suppose that's as close to an apology as you, Can ever get -- If you'll excuse me.... He makes a gesture to stop her, but she brushes past him. We hear Klaus' voice.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS' VOICE
dialogues.text: Rolf -- Steiner turns to face Klaus.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: She's here --!

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (Pre-occupied) Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know -- Ilse -- the Iron Cross Tits --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Listen I don't want -- He has turned automatically to look toward the corner of the bar. At the sight of the GIRL in the nurse's white uniform, Steiner's speech stops; his eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is looking toward Steiner, an expectant smile on her face. She is very buxom and very pretty in a coarse way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steiner's face is expressionless. CAMERA TRUCKING with him, he makes his way to the Waiting Ilse. En route he passes Gertrud who, struck by the grimness of Steiner's expression, keeps her eyes on him as he pushes toward Ils

dialogues.speaker: ILSE
dialogues.text: Her smile freezes as Steiner STEPS INTO the SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (steadily) Good evening, Ilse. She can only stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I can't blame you, Ilse. After all, it's been -- how long --? More than a year anyway. Yes, thirteen months --

dialogues.speaker: ILSE
dialogues.text: (in a very low voice) Rolf --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: -- and the law of averages -- What right have I to be alive -- Did you count on that, Ilse? Suddenly, Ilse lets out a sob, covers her face with her then turns and runs toward the exit. Klaus, who has stood few paces behind, comes up to Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: I must say -- it's a strange effect you have upon women. Steiner doesn't answer. Klaus shakes his head, goes after Ilse.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Whose eyes haven't left Steiner. She watches him now as h sits down at an unoccupied table. From his inside pocket he takes out a piece of paper. She sees him flag a passin WAITER. A brief conversation ensues between them, and the Waiter lends Steiner a pencil. As Steiner begins to write Gertrud moves slowly toward him.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER AT TABLE WRITING
dialogues.text: As Gertrud's shadow falls across the table he looks up briefly, goes back to his writing. Without a word, Gertru slips into a chair across from Steiner. After a moment, h finishes writing, looks at Gertrud.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I imagine you want to know what it's all about?

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Be honest.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. Very much. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: It's not too pretty a story -- and it  isn't very chivalrous of me to tell it. But, then, one of the first casualties of the war was chivalry -- (looks at the slip of paper) A year or so ago I was in a hospital. In four years of war I have been in four hospitals. (harshlaugh) Some day I must get around to rating them. Anyway -- Ilse -- Miss Bauman -- decided she would be more than a nurse to me. After three days and three nights I told her to be more than a nurse to somebody else. (looks at Gertrud's face) He is silent a moment, his face reflecting the humiliatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She found a way to get even -- result -- Court martial -- degraded -- Six months in a Penal Battalion -- (pause. Holds up the paper) Now, I in tend to have Miss Bauman's signed confession --

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Please -- don't be brutal to her -- He gets up. She looks at him in mute appeal. He shakes his head, Starts out, Gertrud looking after him. He gets up. She looks at him in mute appeal. He shakes his head, star out, Gertrud looking after him.

dialogues.speaker: BENCH ON BEACH
dialogues.text: On a corner of the bench, Ilse is huddled, still sobbing In the b.g. a figure looms. Then a flashlight, in the hand of the figure is snapped on. Its beam ILLUMINATES Ilse, who doesn't move. The figure, holding the flashligh moves closer, and we SEE that it is Steiner. Now he stand beside Ilse, who does not look up.

dialogues.speaker: ILSE
dialogues.text: Turn it out -- I can't see. Steiner snaps off the light. She looks up at him, her fac a study in fury.

dialogues.speaker: ILSE
dialogues.text: You Stinking louse.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (laughs grimly) I that What I am?

dialogues.speaker: ILSE
dialogues.text: (violently) Yes. And you always were a louse. You never knew how to treat a woman.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: How right you are. And now, let me prove your point -- (takes Out the Slip Of paper) -- Sign this.

dialogues.speaker: ILSE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Your confession.

dialogues.speaker: ILSE
dialogues.text: Confession. What have I to confess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- are we going to play games? All right, I'll read it to you -- (snaps on the flashlight, starts to read) On the night of May 12, 1943, I, Ilse Bauman, a nurse at the 2nd Base Hospital in Rostov, stole a wrist- watch from the room of Corporal Karl Wachtel, an amputee, and furthermore, hid the watch among the belongings of -- Sgt. Rolf Steiner. Suddenly, Ilse jumps to her feet, starts to run, knocking the flashlight from Steiner's hands. But Steiner catches her in two strides. She kicks him and pummels him with he fists. Steiner drags her down to the water, wades in kne deep and thrusts her head under.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: holding Ilse's head under water. Then he pulls her up by the hair.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Will you sign now? She coughs and struggles for breath. He picks her up in h arms, carries her back to the bench, dumps her on it unce moniously. He picks up the pencil and paper and the flash light. He flashes the LIGHT on her face. Water is drippin from her hair down her forehead and onto her hands.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Maybe in bed you could cry your way out, but not here. He thrusts the pencil into her hand. He flashes the LIGHT  on the bench so that Ilse can see. With trembling hands, she signs the paper. Steiner switches off the flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (looking at paper) All right -- you may go now. She doesn't stir.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (repeats sharply) You may go now. Unsteadily, she gets to her feet, looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: ILSE
dialogues.text: (tonelessly) You're going to report me. He nods grimly.

dialogues.speaker: ILSE
dialogues.text: Oh, God. Oh, God, what am I going  to do? He shrugs. Slowly she walks away, her wet skirt clinging to her legs, head bowed, shoulders twitching.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: watching Ilse go. There is no pity in his face. Then, he sits on the bench, examines the paper closely. He is deep in thought when there is the SOUND of SOFT FOOTSTEPS in t sand. Steiner looks up, Gertrud stands beside him.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: (quietly) So you have what you want? Steiner nods his head slowly, looks at the paper again. T he gets up, walks to the water's edge. For a moment, he hesitates, then he tears the paper into tiny scraps, toss them into the water. Gertrud comes INTO the SCENE, stands  at Steiner's side. Together they watch the scraps being carried out on the waves, dancing and scattering until th vanish from sight. There is a moment's silence, broken by Gertrud.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (shrugs; then, slowly) I'm not interested anymore in clearing my name. Doesn't matter..... He starts away.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Rolf-- He stops, turns, looks at Gertrud.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: as she looks steadily toward Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER AND GERTRUD
dialogues.text: He walks to her. Without a word he takes her in his arms. They cling to each other.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Gertrud, her knees drawn up, sits facing the sea. Steiner sits at right angle to Gertrud, his head resting on her shoulder, as he reads a letter:

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: "-- Well, here I am, back in dear old Mother Russia, after six weeks in the hospital. Why did no one eyer tell me before about the pleasures of being wounded? That nice, clean hospital -- the food -- those nurses -- rather, that one  nurse in particular. But why am I telling you. Every hospital, I hear has that one particular specimen... " He turns his head to look at Gertrud. They smile at each other. Then he resumes reading.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Anyway -- "At the moment things are quiet here, so you can be sure the Russkis are preparing something big. I suppose you heard that Dorn got it. We had finally persuaded the professor to put in for Officers Training, and the very next day the Russkis lobbed over a few shells to let us know they're still in business --"  He stops reading. Gertrud looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Bad you heard of it?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Were you fond of him?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: The professor? I don't know -- not particularly, I guess. (reflects a moment) He was a good soldier. Did his job. (pause) I'm sorry he's gone. (back to letter)  "Well, to get on to more cheerful news. Our darling Captain Stransky is in some sort of trouble --" (looks up from letter) Him -- I can be more definite about. (resumes reading) "Seems in the Captain's report on the Russian action, the night we got it, he somewhat overplayed his hand. His report, I hear, pictures Stransky, accompanied by Triebig, appearing at the last moment among his fleeing men, stemming the panic, and leading the counterattack --" (pauses)  A damned lie! (back to letter) "From what I hear, Stransky sat out the engagement in his bunker. Colonel Brandt informed Stransky that he was entitled to the Iron Cross First Class for bis actions, but he also pointed out that two witnesses were required. Triebig, that sweet- smelling skunk, naturally signed, but the signature of the Company Commander was also needed. Since Lieutenant Meyer was killed and you were then in charge, it looks like you're elected. We can't wait until you get back and are asked  to sign. So, don't linger by the wayside. Hurry back and join the fun. Keep well and watch out that they don't pick you up and stick you in some other unit. Things are supposed to be pretty hot on the main front. All the best, your old friend, Schnurrbart." Steiner looks out at the sea. After a moment...

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: You don't want to go back do you?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (Pause) Not now.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: (trying to sound  cheerful) In the morning you're going home for a month. I know it sounds crazy -- out maybe in a month it'll all be over.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: It'll never be over. Not for me. He falls silent. The POUNDING of the SURF can be HEARD. Gertrud stretches her hand out to Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Rolf -- sit beside me. He takes her outstretched hand, sits beside her, rests his head on her breast. She puts her arm around him. He lies quietly for a moment, then lifts his face to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: No, darling -- later -- later -- later -- Her arms around him, she is rocking him almost like a child as we:

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: There are two fleets of army trucks lined up. On one side of the street the trucks face west; on the opposite side they face east. SOLDIERS are boarding both fleets of trucks.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: He calls out to a soldier who is walking hesitantly to- ward the trucks facing west.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: You there -- let me see your orders. The soldier hands his orders to Muller, who looks at then

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Where do you think you are going? (with sadistic glee) These trucks are going home. You belong there -- (Pointing to east- bound trucks) You're going to the front! (pointing to west- bound trucks) Lucky ones there! (waves to east bound trucks) Unlucky ones there! (laughs again)

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: standing outside the rest home, near the parked trucks. H is looking up and down the street -- evidently waiting fo Someone. Muller, who CAN BE SEEN in the b.g. , calls out

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Steiner--! Get into your truck. It's ready to move!

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: as Steiner walks slowly up to him.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Sergeant? For one of the lucky ones, you sure don't seem anxious to go. Steiner doesn't even look at Muller who evidently sees so at the west trucks.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Hey, you there -- let me see your Orders -- He runs off, almost colliding with Inge. She looks compla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Sergeant Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I'm touched. Up this early just to say goodbye to me. Or are you waiting to welcome the new batch coming in?

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: No. I just thought somebody should say goodbye to you. (smiles as Steiner looks at her) Gertrud is not coming, Sergeant. He stares at her. She takes ah envelope out of her pocket

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: This is for you.  As he snatches it out of her hand.....

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: That's all right. I've already read it.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: You're a pig. (looks at the envelope, but doesn't open it)

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: I'll be happy to read it to you. She takes the envelope from him. neither objecting nor assenting. He just stands there, Inge's tone, as she reads, is not as triumphantly smug as might have been expected.

dialogues.speaker: INGE
dialogues.text: (reads)  "Dearest Rolf -- I can't face you this morning. How can you and I know what we feel for each other? We hate so quickly and easily, maybe we fall in love too quickly and easily, too. There are things I even needed to tell you about..... Steiner snatches the letter from Inge. crumples it in his hand. His face is his usual steel mask again. He stands still for a moment, then the SOUND of the truck MOTORS causes him to look up. The trucks bound for the front have started slowly off. Steiner looks at the crumpled letter in his hand, throws it away, runs for the trucks.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: as Steiner runs past him. He stares in amazement as Steiner jumps onto the back of the last truck heading eas

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (almost screaming) No! No! Steiner -- wrong truck! You're going home. That one's going to the front! Steiner -- Steiner -- ! But in the b.g. the truck has disappeared around the corn

dialogues.speaker: ROAD SKIRTING A ROW OF BUNKERS
dialogues.text: A truck is seen coming to a stop. A lone figure jumps off back, waves to the driver. The truck drives on.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: standing in the road, looking about him with some curiosi  Then, CAMERA TRUCKING with him, he starts to walk. He passes several SOLDIERS. We can tell by the cursory glanc they exchange that they are strangers to each other. Steiner enters the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: rounding a corner near the bunker. He HEARS SHOUTS from t bunker and stops. Then he HEARS a half dozen voices CRYIN in unison, "Steiner! Steiner! Steiner!" Triebig's face sets. He stands a moment, immobile, then turns, hurries away in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kruger, Kern, Schnurrbart and Anselm are grouped around Steiner. A NEWCOMER stands off to the side a bit. Steiner is opening a beer bottle.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: You're an idiot, Rolf. Why didn't  you go home when you could have?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (stony-faced) Heard it was safer here. (nodding) I was home for two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: THE NEWCOMER
dialogues.text: (angrily) I wish this kind of talk would stop. It's -- it's gross exaggeration -- and what's more, it has a terrible effect on the morale of the troops at the front! Everyone turns to look at the newcomer. coolly. Steiner regards him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (defiantly) Zoll.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Herr Zoll for worrying about my morale. The men laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: Zoll is a Party member. He's con- vinced we're winning the war, and anybody who doesn't think so, he's quite willing to turn in to the Storm Troops.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (to Zoll) My name is Rolf Steiner -- and please memorize my correct serial number. I wouldn't want them to come for the wrong man. The PHONE RINGS. Zoll answers it.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (very snappy) Second Platoon. Zoll speaking.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: God, isn't it wonderful hearing a real soldier speaking again.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (through the men's laughter) Yes, sir -- yes, sir --  (hangs up, turns to Steiner Captain Stransky wants to see you in his bunker.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: Right away.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Good. I missed my Captain Stransky.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY'S FACE
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK and we SEE that we are in what is evidently Stransky's bunker. Triebig is facing Stransky. It is now dark.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I'll soften him up, don't worry.  How long have we kept him waiting?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: About half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: All right. Send him in. Triebig, still looking worried, goes OUT. Stransky stands for a moment, moves another chair to the table, then sits opposite it. The door opens and Steiner comes IN. He look at Stransky, his face devoid of expression.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: with Steiner in b.g. Stransky's demeanor is carefully matter-of-fact.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Welcome back, Sergeant. Please sit down. (impatiently, as  Steiner remains standing) You may sit down.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: If you order me to.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Consider it an order. Reluctantly, Steiner sits down facing Stransky, who moves kerosene lamp so that he himself is sitting in darkness.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Are you quite recovered from your wound?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Quite.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Good. Now that you're back, I'm  willing to make a fresh start. I excuse your past behavior. There are several important matters I wish to discuss with you.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (his face shows that he knows what Stransky has in mind 1 there is a pause before he speaks) Certain things can be talked about only man to man, not superior to subordinate.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (an attempt at a smile) You would naturally think that.  But, you know, don't you, that in civilian life, too, a distinction is made between people and personalities? For a fleeting moment Steiner's expression darkens, but h quickly composes his features. His tone is ingenuous.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I don't. But I'm'sure you can explain that distinction to me.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (smoothly) I can. The difference is a matter of ethical and intellectual super- iority and is caused, whether you like it or not, by class difference. Those who are reared in dirt will never or rarely emerge from it  because they have never learned to see dirt as dirt. Isn't that self - evident?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (swiftly and quietly I disagree. Talent, sensitivity and character are not privileges of the upper class.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (voice less urbane) I see. May I ask which of the two categories you count yourself? It is an open challenge. Steiner sits up in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Is this conversation taking place between two equal human beings, or  between a superior and his sub- ordinate?

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (haughtily) I see no reason to throw the weight of my rank into the balance.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (quietly) In that case, I am free not to answer your tactless question. There is e silence as fury mounts in Stransky's eyes, but he controls his voice.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: You are forgetting yourself, Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (coldly)  If you feel insecure about standing on your grounds of equality, we can easily go back to our regular relationship.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (looks at his hands, speaks softly) Your impertinence can only come from stupidity -- and digging holes. (stands up brusquely and paces the room several times be- fore he comes to a stop in front of Steiner) I have met more than one person of  your type -- and I have always crushed them like vermin. I consider you nothing more than an insolent lout who cannot keep his hands off his comrades' property.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: as he stands up slowly. He makes a visible effort to control himself.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (voice steady and quiet) You'll regret that.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY AND STEINER
dialogues.text: Steiner wipes his sleeve with his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: For that remark alone, back home I would have had dogs chase you over the fields until your feet were bleeding straps.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: We're not back home.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: You'll wish you were before long. (turns his back on Steiner, picks up the phone) Triebig? Come in here! He hangs up, turns, sees that Steiner is leaning easily against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Stand at attention!  Steiner takes a half step forward, lets his arms dangle. The door opens and Triebig COMES IN.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: How far has my new bunker progressed?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: About a foot and a half.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: The bunker is to be ten feet deep. Sergeant Steiner will work on it tonight until that depth is reached.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (astonished) Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Tonight. I shall hold your respon- sible for having that bunker ready  by tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Steiner has listened with an impassive face. Now, without change of expression, he holds the door open for Triebig, then he turns to look at Stransky. without a word, he GOES OUT.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG AND STEINER
dialogues.text: as they walk toward the spot (seen in b.g.) where the new bunker is being dug. They walk in silence a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: I want you to know I have nothing to do with this business.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: That's lucky for you. (pause)  Where's your "friend"?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (looking straight ahead) He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Oh -- too bad. (sardonically) Well -- bear up. Fresh recruits are coming in every day. Triebig looks at him and his voice shakes with hatred.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: I have only one wish, and the Commander shares it. We could court martial you or get rid of you some other way. But we want  to have the pleasure of seeing you -- croak.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (smiles) You'll have to take very good care of yourself if you want to outlive me. Triebig clenches his fists in helpless fury.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Thank you for the warning.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: You're entirely welcome. By this time they have reached the pit where four men are digging.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (to the men)  Ail right -- you're relieved. You may return to your quarters. The men, seeing only Steiner with Triebig, don't quite comprehend.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (shouting) I said you may return to your quarters! The men hastily drop their shovels, clamber out of the pi and walk AWAY. They keep looking back at Triebig and Steiner, still not certain of what's going on. Triebig turns to Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: If I were you, I'd make sure it was done by morning.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: It won't be for lack of trying, sir. Triebig glowers at him, walks AWAY. Steiner jumps into the pit, starts to shovel. The CAMERA notes that Steiner is up to his kneecaps in the pit.

dialogues.speaker: PAIR OF MUDDY BOOTS
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS UP from the boots to Steiner's face. Steiner is asleep in a chair, his feet stretched out. The scene is the outer room of Brandt's command post. After a moment, the inner door opens and Kiesel and Triebig COME OUT.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: You'll wait here, Lieutenant. Triebig nods nervously, Kiesel looks at Steiner, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steiner! Steiner opens his eyes, stumbles to his feet, straightens up. Kiesel holds the door open. Steiner looks at Triebig, then walks IN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandt is sitting behind a huge, clumsy desk piles with all sorts of useless objects. He holds a lighted cigarett between his fingers. Steiner and Kiesel COME IN.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: So there you are. Next time you're wounded, give me a week's notice that we're going to lose you, ha, ha. How are you, Steiner?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I can't complain.  Brandt stands up, shakes hands heartily, toward chair.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Make yourself comfortable. (extends cigarette case to Steiner) How was it in the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (laconically) Pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: And the Rest Home?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I recommend it.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (laughs, then, casually) then gestures  That night you were wounded -- did you know that Captain Stransky led the Second Company's counter- attack?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: That's what they tell me.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: The counterattack was led by Lieutenant Meyer. Captain Stransky was nowhere in sight. Brandt and Kiesel exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: Are you sure of that?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Absolutely. In the first place, I would have seen him, and in the second place, Lieutenant Meyer had to report to the Captain what had been happening in the lines.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I was there when Lieutenant Meyer phoned.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: A-ha! (sharply, to Kiesel) Fetch Triebig. Kiesel GOES OUT.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (grimly) I think you're entitled to a little fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it opens and Triebig and Kiesel COME IN. Triebig looks very worried. For a moment, Brandt just looks at Triebig who bites his lip. Finally, Brandt speaks. His voice is unusually soft and low.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: You signed your Captain's report, Lieutenant Triebig. Were you present when Captain Stransky led the counterattack?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (after a notice- able hesitation)  I accompanied the commander to the hill and saw him calling several men around him. Then he sent me back to the command post.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Then how do you know that Stransky really led the counterattack? You signed a statement to that effect, Lieutenant Triebig.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: I -- I learned of it from wounded men who were returning.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Can you give me the name of one of these wounded men?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: They weren't staff men -- just company men. I -- I knew them only by sight. Besides, it was pitch dark when I spoke to them.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (icily) I want you to know, Lieutenant Triebig, that I have had your statements checked. Captain Kiesel will inform you of the results of our investigation. Steiner watches closely as Kiesel takes a sheet of paper out of his pocket, studies its contents for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: (placidly) Our investigation so far has  disclosed that at the moment there are forty-two men in 2nd Company who took part in that counterattack. They declare Unanimously that the attack was led by Lieutenant Meyer. None of them saw Captain Stransky, and none of them heard that he was even with the company. Brandt turns to Triebig, who looks ds if he were standing against a wall watching an execution squad line up in fro of him.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: To my mind, there is nothing more contemptible than snatching the laurels that properly belong to  a man who died in action. I shall abide by Sergeant Steiner's testimony. If he stands by his statement that Captain Stransky was not with the company, I shall be compelled to institute disciplinary proceedings against the Captain. You may go now. You are no longer needed here.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He doesn't look at Steiner as he LEAVES the room.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (to Steiner) Very well. Do you stand by your  statement? To Brandt's surprise, Steiner doesn't answer immediately. Then, after some hesitation:

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Would it be possible for me to think it over for a few days?

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (anger and disappoint- ment in his voice) Think it over? What is there to think over? Did you see Stransky or not? Steiner doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: I don't understand you. Are you a friend of Stransky's? My im-  pression is that you wish him in hell.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: My differences with Captain Stransky are a private matter.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (losing patience) Oh, they are? Why were you ordered to dig Stransky's bunker tonight? Steiner compresses his lips.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: I asked you something! Steiner looks up, their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Do you want to hear lies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning forward) Do you know that Stransky intends to recommend disciplining you?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (a growl) If I were he, I wouldn't lose a minute about it.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (to Kiesel) I really think I should place a guard over him and have him dig holes until he's blue in the face.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: (shrugs)  Why try to revise the decisions of Providence?

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (sternly, to Steiner) Listen to me. You know I've always shown a great deal of understanding for you. But I am beginning to get tired of battling with your superiors over you.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (defiantly) I didn't ask you to. AS soon as the words are out, it is obvious from Steiner' expression that he regrets going that far, but it is too late. Brandt rises and leans on his desk. His voice is hoarse with rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't ask me to! You didn't ask me to! Have you gone clean out of your mind? Do you have any idea what you're saying?

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: Steiner -- you ungrateful idiot -- For a second, Steiner closes his eyes. Se is struggling not to let the words out -- but they come pouring forth violently.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: What are you asking me, Captain Kiesel? To love Colonel Brandt? I hate Colonel Brandt. I hate you, Captain Kiesel, and Stransky and Triebig, and ever since I've  put on this damn uniform I've hated everybody and anybody connected with it. If I get into any trouble, if I have any problem with anything or anybody, I'll solve them myself --! Thank you very much! Me pauses, shaking. There is a dead silence in the room. Brandt is breathing heavily. His unsteady hands grope across the top of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (his voice broken) Get out. Get out of here at once! Steiner doesn't move for a split second, then he GOES OUT Brandt tries to regain control of himself. Kiesel looks at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: all headed west. This is followed by QUICK CUTS of the troop-laden trucks. The total impression is of a gigantic exodus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steiner, Schnurrbart, Kruger, Zoll, and Anselm are all present. They have packed all their belongings, ready to move out. Schnurrbart and Kruger are playing cards. Steiner is sitting quietly on his bunk. The others are moving about -- obviously beset by impatience. Why the hell aren't we moving out?

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: What's everybody so worried about? Moving a regiment is quite a job, let me tell you. It doesn't move all at once. The PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: Ah -- that's probably our orders now. AS Steiner goes to the phone, everybody makes for their packs, ready to leave at the word.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
