dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes -- yes, sir -- I see -- (no change of expression)  Yes, sir -- at what time? -- Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: (to Steiner, who has hung up) What's the good word?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: The good word is that we've been elected. (cautiously) Elected to -- what?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Captain Stransky's paid us a great honor. We -- that is, our platoon -- is to stay here as a rear guard  until dark. For two hours. Maybe three. The men are frozen in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I think we ought to feel very proud.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: Those idiots are crazy.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: Not so crazy. They're pulling out, we're not.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (takes a map from his pocket, spreads it on the table, traces with his thumb)  The division is moving back to new positions east of Krimskaya --

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (nodding) Much easier to launch an offensive from there.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: Why us? Of all the platoons in the battalion, why us? (violently) Because our sergeant is such a pal of Captain Stransky'e! That's why us!

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. In the next war I'll try  to pick my enemies more carefully.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF CAR
dialogues.text: The car stands outside Stransky's bunker. A military CHAUFFEUR is at the wheel, and the MOTOR is RUNNING. A steady stream of trucks and equipment, headed west, flows past the staff car. In the b.g. the door to Stransk bunker flies open and the Captain with Lieutenant Triebig behind him, STEPS OUT. As they make for the car, the phon within the bunker is HEARD RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Stransky comes INTO the SCENE, picks up phone. Triebig is in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Captain Stransky -- Yes, yes, Captain Kiesel, we were just about to leave -- Yes, sir --  What's that, sir? (his expression is cloudy as he listens) I see, sir. Yes, sir. I'll attend to that immediately. Yes, sir. He hangs up. Triebig looks at him inquiringly.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Intelligence reports that the Russians are already on the high- way. Regiment feels that it would be not only useless but suicidal to leave behind any rear guard platoons. They're to join the evacuation immediately.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: I see.  He and Stransky exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Shall I call -- I believe it's Sergeant Steiner's platoon, is it not? Stransky nods. Triebig waits for him to say something, but he doesn't so Triebig picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Just a second, Lieutenant -- Triebig turns to face Stransky.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: What do you think of this story? We tried to establish telephone communication with Steiner's bunker, but evidently his wires had already been cut. You, Lieuten-  ant Triebig, upon personal investigation, discovered their bunker abandoned. Apparently, the platoon had already left to take up its forward position. The two men look at each other. Then!

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (slowly) I think it's an excellent story.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Just a story?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Much more than a story. I think it's fully justified.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: You do? Why?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (after a moment's thought) It is my firm conviction that the Third Reich would be better off without the likes of Steiner and his cronies. The two men stand looking at each other without speaking. Then Stransky takes the telephone wire in his two hands and yanks it out of the wall. He doesn't look at Triebig as he strides from the bunker. Triebig follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the men, with the exception of Steiner, are present. They are busy packing ammunition boxes.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: Damn it. I hate to leave this place. We worked weeks fixing this place up -- this damn army.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: The trouble with you is -- you're scared stiff.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (looks at him) You don't know how grateful we are that you were sent to us. It's nice to have one brave man in the platoon.

dialogues.speaker: AT DOOR
dialogues.text: as it opens, and Steiner, his uniform wringing wet, COMES IN.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Well -- are we all still here? What do you mean "still here"?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (pretending surprise) No deserters? (walking to table) All right, then, let's have a look at the map before we start. He looks at map. The men gather around him. How far is it to Krimskaya?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: About twenty miles. (staring thought- fully at the map)  The stuff between is regular wilderness. And a stream running through. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: STEINER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How big a stream? Suppose there's no bridge? And the whole region is marshy. The big question is whether we can get through.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Then let's use the highway. Steiner just looks at him. (anxiously) What does that look mean? Did you see any Russians on the high-  way?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Infantry, trucks, tanks, the whole damn Russian army. There is a moment's silence. On the highway?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Not in the air, take my word for it.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (strapping on ammuni- tion box) How are we going to cross the highway with the Russians on it?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: It's dark, it's raining--and there are bound to be a few gaps in the procession. We'll wait for the right moment and scoot across. It's hopeless. It's just plain suicide.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (slinging his tommy gun over his shoulder) We're eight self-reliant, resource- ful Germans. We'll make it.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (sardonically to Kern) There! Do you feel better?  Suppose we do make it. The Russians will be in Krimskaya before us. That means to get to our lines, we'll have to cross theirs. How? How, I'm asking?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (his boxes are strapped to him) We can tunnel beneath the Russians -- or we can pole vault over them. Are we all ready? (groaning) You can joke, but we're finished. Finished.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Of course we are. No doubt about it. And because you have so brilliantly pointed that out, you may lead the way. He flings the door open I motions for Kern to start the exodus. Kern looks sour, but leads the way. The others squeeze past Steiner at the door. When they are GONE, Steiner kicks the stove so that it falls over, spilling its golden embers on the floor. Then he GOES OUT, closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: THE PLATOON
dialogues.text: huddled together in the rain, waiting for Steiner. After a moment, he comes INTO the SCENE. He jerks his head in the direction he wishes them to take. Then he starts off. The men exchange glances, but no one says a word. They trudge off.

dialogues.speaker: OPEN PLOWLANO
dialogues.text: It is still dark, but in the east the sky is beginning to lighten. In the distance WE SEE the line of men walking slowly, their heads bent against the rain.

dialogues.speaker: THE MEN WALKING
dialogues.text: The ANGLE FAVORS Zoll and Kern. They are panting under th burden of their machine-guns and boxes of ammunition. They are cursing under their breaths. The CAMERA PANS DOWN to their boots. They are caked with great lumps of muddy soil.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: His face expressionless, he is walking steadily on. Ahead of him the terrain begins to slope upward. Suddenly, Steiner stops in his tracks r holds his hands up for the men to stop.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: What the devil's the matter now? No one answers. Schnurrbart motions for them to listen. After a moment, the low DRONE of big MOTORS, the CREAKING of heavily laden TRUCKS is HEARD. Also an occasional windblown SHOUT is HEARD.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (whispering) Russians. (nervously) A whole army. With quivering fingers he unthinkingly reaches for his cigarettes and thrusts one between his lips. As he strike a match, Steiner suddenly APPEARS in front of him. There  is a sharp SLAPPING SOUND, followed by a RAIN of SPARKS from the crushed cigarette. Kern utters a whimpering sound and presses both hands against his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (voice thick with rage) You idiot! The men look at him in alarm, but he whirls around and runs forward, signaling for the men to follow.

dialogues.speaker: KERN
dialogues.text: as he walks along. There is a burn on his upper lip which he pats tenderly. His face is clouded with resent- ment. The VOICES ahead become increasingly distinct. The crisp TREAD of nailed boots is very marked -- grows even louder.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: signaling for the men to halt. He walks back to the group.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (to Schnurrbart and Anselm) You come with me. The rest will wait here. Steiner, Anselm and Schnurrbart run off. The men watch th as, bent low, they DISAPPEAR into the darkness. Then, one by one, the men sink down onto the wet ground. For a few moments no one has the strength or the inclination to speak. Then --

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: He shouldn't have hit you.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's more important than the treatment of one German soldier by another -- I'd like to know.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what's more important -- (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (brings his face close to Zoll's) It's more important that we have to get out of here. And you know why? I'll tell you -- He pokes his finger into Zoll's chest. back.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Zoll moves indignantly  We have to get out so that we'll be on time to get into the next mess. Out of one mess into the next. That's been going on for three years, and it'll go on until we get into one mess good and deep and don't come out of it -- He has worked himself into such a rage that he can't go o There is another morose silence. Zoll sits up on one elbow, listens.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: I think all that activity on the highway is slackening. Don't worry. We'll never get across.  He stops, for everyone is listening intently. He listens too. There isn't a sound from the direction of the highwa (whispering) I don't hear a thing....

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Here comes somebody -- Every head turns.

dialogues.speaker: A FIGURE COMING OUT OF THE MIST
dialogues.text: From the group's P.O.V. The figure stops.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: It's Anselm. Anselm stops, waves his fist in the air.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Let's go.  They snatch their guns, run up the slope, DISAPPEAR into the mist.

dialogues.speaker: CROWN OF HILL
dialogues.text: Beneath it lies the highway in the gray dawn LIGHT. Deserted. In the b.g. WE SEE the platoon slipping down the steep decline and racing across the trampled, rutted width of the road toward the edge of the woods which rise like a dark wall against the further mountains.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: He is standing about 100 yards in the forest, looking tow the highway. The men can be seen running towards him. In a few seconds, they reach Steiner. As they fight to catch their breaths, Steiner looks at them, triumph in hi eyes. Well --  Steiner holds up his hand for quiet. rumble of vehicles can be HEARD from the highway.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: (grinning) Now that we're here that sounds like music to me.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (dryly) I think it's a little early for congratulations. (picks up his gear) We're ready.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: Sergeant -- Steiner turns to regard him.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: They listen. The  Before we start, there's a matter I'd like to bring up. The matter of your treatment of a comrade, Private Kern. Steiner looks at him closely.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: One soldier of the Fuhrer is just as -- good as -- He wilts under Steiner's gaze, stops.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (coldly) Please continue. Just as good as what?

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (weakening) Anyway -- I believe I speak for  all the others -- Steiner looks at the others. (to Zoll) Why don't you mind your own lousy business! It was idiotic of me to light that cigarette. Now, let's go. Steiner looks at Zoll, then, without a word, turns and starts walking. The others follow.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: The scene is one of great bustle and activity. Trucks are unloading. Anti-aircraft guns are being set up on empty lots between houses. A Staff car speeds INTO the SCENE, jolts to a stop before one of the houses. Captain Kiesel  alights, taking a salute from the SENTRY, ENTERS one of the houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: are supervising the installation of phones. Kiesel comes RUNNING IN.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: You're slow with those phones, Captain. Regiment has been trying to speak to you.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: They'll be in any minute, Captain Kiesel.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: with the Russians breathing down our necks, the Colonel wants a patrol out front. I think Steiner's  the most experienced --

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Captain. I haven't the faintest idea of the whereabouts of Steiner and his platoon.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: What do you mean by that? (stares at Stransky) You mean you didn't pull him out of line and bring him back? You had your orders.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I tried to contact Steiner immediately -- wasn't that so, Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Yes, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he had already moved his platoon from the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: Why? He had orders not to move till dark.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (shrugging) You know Steiner Disobeying orders is a speciality of his.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: How the devil is he going to get back here? He's got the whole Russian army to get through.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: He had his orders--he disregarded  them.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: It doesn't sound like Steiner. He'd risk his own neck, not a whole platoon's -- (looks at Stransky closely) I think I can promise you a full investigation, Captain Stransky, when Steiner gets back. If he gets back. He turns and walks OUT rapidly. The telephone men are still in the room, so Stransky and Triebig can only excha covert congratulatory glances. The CAMERA MOVES to the window, THROUGH IT to an open field and as it MOVES EAST.

dialogues.speaker: THICK WOODS
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES DOWN through thorny undergrowth until it picks up Steiner's platoon, fighting their weary way through. The undergrowth has ripped the men's uniforms and scratched their hands and faces. Sweat is pouring from their faces. They are almost continually s lapping a almost invisible stinging mites which hover about them. The CAMERA PANS DOWN to two pair of boots slogging throug the marsh. It is evident that they are suffering a great deal.

dialogues.speaker: THE SUN LOW IN THE SKY
dialogues.text: It will be dark in a little while. From THIS ANGLE the CAMERA ZOOMS DOWN into the forest. It picks out Steiner trudging in water that is halfway up to his knees. There is no one in sight behind him. Suddenly, from the rear there are HOARSE SHOUTS. Steiner stops, turns,  listens. The SHOUTS are HEARD again. Steiner starts back, CAMERA TRUCKING with him. There is a slight rise in the terrain, which is firm and dry. are stretched out on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: What's the trouble?

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: You'll have to call a rest, Rolf.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (tersely) We're not even half way yet.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: I know, but what can't be done can't be done.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Most of the men  All right. He notices Zoll, who is lying on his stomach off to one side, his head pillowed in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Where are your ammunition boxes? The others become attentive. Zoll doesn't stir. Steiner digs the toe of his boot into Zoll's side.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (a grunt) Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: He had them ten minutes ago. The swine must have dumped them.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Then he'll go back for them. Zoll still doesn't move, so Steiner grips him by his cartridge belt and pulls him to his feet. Face twisted with fury, Zoll whirls, snatches up his rifle, brandishes it.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (hoarsely) Keep your dirty paws off me. If you touch me again. Steiner looks into Zoll's rabid face with a sort of curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (quietly) You're too much of a coward. Watch! He drops his tommy gun and gestures Schnurrbart and Kruge  back. They watch worriedly as Steiner steps so close to Zoll that the barrel of his rifle touches his stomach. Quietly he reaches out, grasps the rifle by the barrel an takes it from Zoll's hands. A sort of relieved sigh goes up from the men. Zoll stands motionless, his face re- flecting fear, rage and shame. Steiner picks up his tommy gun.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Get those boxes. Zoll hesitates for just a second. Then he turns and walks off INTO the brush. The men look after him grimly.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: making his way to the top. When he nears it, he pushes aside two branches to give himself a view.

dialogues.speaker: FROM STEINER'S POV
dialogues.text: An enormous expanse of reeds cuts a swath across the  woods. Brown water shimmers along the thick stems. Then there is a hundred yard width of muddy water, then more weeds.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: He looks grim as he starts his descent.

dialogues.speaker: THE MEN
dialogues.text: as they wait for Steiner. I bet this is the only dry spot for miles around. Why don't we just stay here?

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: Don't be silly. They won't know where to send our pay. Ah -- For Steiner has dropped out of the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- ?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Reeds, swamp, open water, more reeds, more swamp. Worse than I thought it would be. Steiner spreads the map on the ground. The men look over his shoulders. Steiner points to something on the map.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (nods) Tomorrow morning we'll start before dawn.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: (querulously) Straight into the creek?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Shut up! We'll march north to the road. How far is that?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: About thirty miles.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Thirty miles! It's crazy! This way we're no more than eight miles from Krimskaya!

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Sure. If we could cross that swamp, and we can't!

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Before I march thirty miles I need something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you've got to have something to eat, try tree bark. Boiled in soft water it's supposed to be edible. Damn it all, don't act like a bunch of children. They look shame-faced, but Kruger growls...

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: You've seen what the water looks like. Like a hundred cows have been scheissing in it.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Then boil it and skim it. You won't mind the filth -- you've got a pig's stomach anyway. The men grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll make a soup. Put the meat and bread right in it. Kruger and Schnurrbart fetch water. But don't anybody try drinking the muck before it's boiled. The rest of us can gather wood. The men make a movement to start.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Wait a minute -- we may as well settle this now. We'll need a volunteer for sentry duty tonight. At least to start it off -- Nobody answers. The men don't look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I know you're all tired, but --  Sergeant, I -- At this moment, a NOISE in the brush causes all heads to turn. An exhausted Zoll, lugging the ammunition boxes' struggles INTO the SCENE. Steiner looks at him, then turn to Kern.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: That's all right. The problem is solved. The men laugh, start off. Zoll looks puzzled by the laugh

dialogues.speaker: SMALL SMOLDERING CAMP FIRE
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK to REVEAL Kruger, Schnurrbart, Kern and Anselm asleep on the ground in various uncomfortable postures. Pawn is breaking in the sky. The air is filled with the croaking SOUND of FROGS.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: as he slowly awakens. It is a moment before he is fully awake. He reaches out and nudges Kern awake. Huh? -- What? -- Oh -- what's up?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Where's Steiner, do you know? He just got up sometime ago and went off somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Did he say where? By this time the conversation has awakened the other men. I asked him, but you know Steiner -- he just gave me a look and off  he went. I got the shits.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: (grimly) Steiner goes -- and you get scared' huh?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: (looks around at all the faces) We're all scared the minute Rolf's not around to hold our hands.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: (tosses a branch into the fire, sending up a shower of sparks) He'll be back. Anselm, relieve Zoll.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (rebelliously) Why me?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Hurry up and relieve Zoll. On the double.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: You and Schnurrbart -- big shots! Lousy noncoms! You're all alike. Rank goes right to your heads. It stinks. The whole damned army stinks. And you, Kruger, stink worst of all! Kruger picks up a dry stick of wood which is only partial in the fire and tosses it at Anselm, who barely throws hi hand up in time. Then, with a cry of rage, he jumps acros the firs and onto Kruger's neck. The two men struggle on  the ground.

dialogues.speaker: KERN, SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: (simultaneously) Come on, now - stop it. Kruger! Anselm! Zoll comes running IN from his sentry post.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: What's going on here? Zoll, assisted by Kern, tries to separate the two men who are locked together on the ground. Watch out -- somebody's going to get burned in the fire! Suddenly, Steiner's voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Zoll -- Kern! Let them fight it out.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: His gun is in the back of an elderly RUSSIAN. The others are in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Why shouldn't they kill each other? Why should the Russians have to do it?

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: Who the hell is that? The old man sinks to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: It's my guess he's a very old Russian -- what's yours?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Where did you find him, Rolf?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: There's a dirt road about four miles from here. The road leads to a bridge. He was guarding it.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: A bridge! A bridge that crosses the swamp, you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: Eureka, that means we don't have to march thirty miles to the highway, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: KERN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Not to mention the forty more to Krimskaya.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (feeling his throat)  Doesn't anybody care that my neck is broken?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Not so fast. On the other side of the bridge there's a house. and there are Russians in the house. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: How do you know -- did you see any?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: No, but there was smoke coming out of the chimney. You ask him how many there are. Kruger talks in Russian to the old man, who replies. Then

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: He says there's two wagons and  two horses.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: To hell with that. Ask him how many men there are in that house. Kruger speaks in Russian, but the old man just shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: How many men are there in the house? Kruger speaks to the old man who closes his eyes and turn his head aside.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: He won't say.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (putting the muzzle of his gun against  the old man's head He has to. Ask him again. Kruger expostulates with the Russian, illustrating his wo with unmistakable gestures. The Russian slowly opens his eyes. Steiner is regarding him without expression. A brief smile passes over the Russian's wrinkled, parchment like face, and he says a few words.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: What is he saying?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: He says he is an old man.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (calmly) We can see that. I admire him, but I'm going to have to shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: Isn't it dangerous, firing a shot? There may be some of them around, looking for him.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: You may be right. On the other hand, we can't waste time hanging him. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: Well, let's see -- there's strangu- lation, drowning, stoning --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: If we had the time we'd let you talk him to death. Pause. Steiner takes a knife from his scabbard. The men are very silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any volunteers?

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (after a moment) How about you, Zoll? You were a butcher in civilian life, weren't you? The joke falls flat, even with Anselm.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (after a moment) If everybody's scared, I might have a try at it.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: No. I'll make it quick and clean. (lifts the Russian to his feet, to  Kruger) We'll give him one more chance. Tell him what I'm going to do. Kruger speaks to the Russian who says nothing, doesn't even shake his head.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: All right, then -- He pushes the Russian ahead of him toward a grove of smal trees, CAMERA TRUCKING with them.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: They stand around in silence. A low GASP is HEARD O.S. The men tense. Anselm ventures to look off.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM'S POV
dialogues.text: Steiner is seen bent over, leaning against a tree.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: I'll say this for Steiner. At least he's throwing up. All eyes are fixed o.s. After a few moments, Steiner comes back IN. His knife and scabbard are both gone.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: All right, get your things together.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: I wonder how many Russians there are in that house.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Since we've got to cross that bridge, it doesn't matter how many there are. Aren't we too few for the job?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: No. There's only the front door  and one window on the side. We'll smoke them out with grenades, then mow them down as they come out. (looks at Zoll) And hang on to your ammunition boxes. We're going to need them. Steiner picks up his pack.

dialogues.speaker: A ONE-STORY HOUSE
dialogues.text: It is made of massive logs. Smoke is pouring from one of the chimneys. The CAMERA STARTS PULLING BACK and we see that a creek flows parallel to the house. Its bank is overgrown with shoulder-high reeds which sway gently in the wind. Two unhitched wagons, their contents concealed under dark brown canvas' stand by the side of the house. Then we see a primitive but wide wooden bridge with rails on both sides. In the center, leaning against the narrow slats of the railing, stands a GUARD -- an elderly man w a yellow, wrinkled face. His cap is pushed back on his head and he is staring dully at the dirty surface of the water. His tommy gun is slung diagonally across his back. The CAMERA CONTINUES BACKWARD across the bridge into the reeds. Finally, it comes to rest on the flattened shapes of Steiner and his platoon who are gazing intently at the sight. The men speak in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: You realize how important it is that no one -- not a single one -- escapes? We won't be able to get them all.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: We have to get them all. Once the  Russians find out there are Germans behind their lines there'll be hundreds of them beating the bushes for us. He looks at the men significantly. They nod grimly.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Anselm -- you and Kruger stay here. Set up the machine gun -- see that no one gets past this way. The rest will come with me. Keep your heads behind the trees -- and remember, if one of them gets away we're sunk. with bent back, he moves forward, the men following. Anselm starts setting up the machine gun.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER AND MEN
dialogues.text: walking cautiously through the woods to get on the other  side of the house. The CAMERA FOCUSES on Zoll, who is last in line. His eyes are fixed on the ground, on small patches of SUNLIGHT on the ground. They change shape, expand and contract each time the leaves stir overhead. Suddenly Zoll takes mincing little steps, now jumping or skipping to avoid a band of SUNLIGHT. He becomes so absorbed in this that he is oblivious to everything else. He doesn't notice that Steiner is standing in his path, watching him curiously. Zoll is on the point of jumping over a broad s trip of LIGHT when his eyes meet Steiner's His intended jump becomes a halting step that carries him right into the middle of the SUNLIT band. Zo11 stands still, looking into Steiner's face.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (weak smile) Just a game --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulously) A what? A game?

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (apologetically When we were kids -- a came -- we'd race through the woods. No one was allowed to step on a spot of sunlight --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I see. And would you like us to join you in the game? Perhaps we could find the time.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: I only thought -- silly idea -- if I don't step on a spot of sunlight  now I'd come through this all right. He smiles an abject, apologetic smile. Steiner's face is expressionless. He turns to the men, motions them to the ground. Zoll is the last to obey.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER ON THE GROUND
dialogues.text: The men behind him.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I'll take care of the gentleman on the bridge. When I run -- you follow me -- (looks at Zoll) -- taking special care to avoid the spots of sunlight. Zoll flashes a look of hatred at Steiner, but remains qui Steiner lifts his tommy gun, sights it at the man on the bridge. He takes his time. Beside him, Kern is trembling  visibly.

dialogues.speaker: THE GUARD ON THE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: He has not changed his position.

dialogues.speaker: OVER STEINER'S SHOULDER
dialogues.text: SHOOTING TOWARD the Guard in the b.g. Steiner is still aiming. Then he FIRES -- a whipping round of SHOTS. In the b.g., SEE the man on the bridge start to move as though he stoo on a whirling disc. Then his hands grip the wooden railin for support. His legs sag, and he slides, knees first, underneath the railing and into the dirty water. Steiner jumps to his feet, runs madly for the bridge, the men following.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER SIDE OF BRIDGE
dialogues.text: as Steiner comes across, throws himself flat on the groun The others, close behind, do the same. They all SHOOT  round after round at the doors of the hut. Then --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (holding up his hand) Stop! A FINAL BURST from Kern and then there is stillness. The men look toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: There is not a sound from the house. Not a single sign of any activity.

dialogues.speaker: THE MEN
dialogues.text: still lying flat on their stomachs. They turn their faces to look at each other questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (hopefully) Maybe there's nobody in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, there is.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: Well, it can't be too large a force. Enough to give us a hero's death.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: (to Steiner) What do you make of it? (excitedly) Look -- ! A figure is rushing toward them.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Don't shoot -- it's Kruger!  Kruger comes RUNNING IN, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Rolf --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (sharply) Why did you leave your post? Anselm can't handle them alone.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Anselm is in the house.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear the screaming?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Screaming? (looks at the men  for confirmation)

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Women's screams, then moans. So Anselm went in. (bitterly) Naturally. If it's anything to do with women --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: What do you mean, women?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: I mean women! Anselm says to come over.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Well, it's nice of him to invite us. Kern, you stay outside. Fire.  one shot if you see anyone coming. He gets up, runs toward the house, the men following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Steiner comes INTO the SCENE, kicks open the front doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a narrow hall, which separates two rooms. From the left room comes a weird MOAN. The men look at each other. Steiner walks to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire long wall of the room is taken up by a heap of straw covered with blankets. Crowded together in the rear half of the room, faces half-defiant, half-terrified, are about a dozen and a half WOMEN in Russian uniforms. They carry no weapons. Most of them are big breasted, stocky women. Their full blouses, reaching down over their hips are gathered at the waist by broad belts. One or two are fairly young and attractive, and there is one exceed ingly pretty GIRL. At the women's feet, bedded down on the straw, lies a young WOMAN, the clothing stripped away from the upper part of her body, a blood-soaked bandage Covering her right breast. Her eyes are closed, she emits the weird MOAN. Anselm is guarding them. Steiner and the men stop in thei tracks as they see the women.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (grinning broadly) I hope you put me in for the Iron Cross, Sergeant. I took them single-handed.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Well, what do we do with them?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: What do you do with armed guerrillas, male or female?

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: These are not guerrillas. They're regular uniformed troops. Besides -- they had no arms.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: If they're regular troops, we'll treat them as we must treat all prisoners in our situation.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: (gasping) You mean, shoot them?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Do you see any other way? If one of them escapes and gets to  the Russian lines before us, we're done for.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: Steiner is right. The women must be killed.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (looks at Zoll) Despite the fact that you agree with me, I still feel I'm right. His glance falls on the wounded woman. him with an expression of wild horror. beside her speaks in Russian.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: What did she say, Kruger?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: She says there's a kettle of hot She is looking at An older WOMAN  water in the room across the hall. Please help the girl, she says.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Anselm, get the water. We'll clean the wound.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (bewildered) What's the sense of fixing her up, if you're going to shoot her?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (sharply) Get the water. Anselm shrugs, GOES OUT.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (to Kruger)  Ask them where they come from and where they were going. Tell them if they lie to us we'll throw them in the creek. Kruger talks in Russian, the older Woman, who appears to be an officer, replies.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: (to Steiner) They belong to the B d th Women's Mortar Battalion and are on their way from Maihop to Krimskaya. I think she's telling the truth. Steiner looks grim. Anselm COMES IN with a bowl of hot water, sets it on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER AND WOUNDED WOMAN
dialogues.text: as he bends down beside her. She tries to roll back  against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Take it easy. What do you think I want to do? He lifts the bandage. We do not see the wound, but from Steiner's face, we know that it is a serious one.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (opening his first aid kit) Are you in pain? The woman understands, nods.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (enigmatically) The pain will be over soon. He starts to wash the wound. In the b.g., we CAN SEE that the other women have not changed their posture. They  are still huddled together against the wall, fearfully watching his movements. Steiner lays a compress on the wound.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. A nice clean bandage -- then a bullet. Before Steiner can reply there is a NOISE at the door.

dialogues.speaker: KERN AND OLD RUSSIAN
dialogues.text: Kern has his gun in the Russian's back. The Russian is squat and stocky and despite his age looks powerful. (grinning proudly) He practically walked into our arms --

dialogues.speaker: OLD RUSSIAN
dialogues.text: (to Steiner, raising  his hand pleadingly) Captain -- Steiner pushes him in the direction of the women, motions for him to lie down. As the old man reels, several of the women SCREAM. I had a look at the wagons, Sergeant -- there's plenty of food. Canned. stuff.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Good. Zoll, you stay here. If any of the women starts anything, shoot her at once.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (as they walk off) When do I get to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be in such a hurry. Who wants to eat? He starts OUT.

dialogues.speaker: PAIR OF HIGHLY POLISHED OFFICER'S BOOTS
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS UP to a MED. SHOT of Colonel Brandt on the telephone. The scene is obviously his new headquarters in Krimskaya, the second floor of a Russian building. Captain Kiesel stands near the window, listening.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Yes, General.... Yes, General, we're so solidly dug in, it seems almost a shame -- (smiles ironically at Kiesel) I say that, General, because in  four or five days -- we'll be driven out of these beautifully dug-in positions. (another smile to Kiesel) Certainly, General. I know about German valor. without that valor, I wouldn't give us more than two days -- Yes, General. I will, sir. (hangs up, shrugs in Kiesel'S direction) The General was short with me; but he knows the truth as well as I do.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: Of course. It's always he who  orders us to fall back, isn't it? There is a KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Come in. An ORDERLY opens the door for a CAPTAIN.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN KILIUS
dialogues.text: Captain Kilius reporting, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. You have your orders?

dialogues.speaker: KILIUS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. And a letter for you.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (as he opens the envelope) This is Captain Kiesel-- Kiesel and Kilius shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Kilius comes to us from the Western Front.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: Really? Whatever induced you to leave, Captain? Kilius smiles wanly. Brandt, reading the letter, snorts loudly.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Didn't you once mention Captain Stransky's good connections?

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: There is a Major General Stransky attached to Army High Command, South. He is, I think, a cousin of Captain Stransky's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. (tosses letter on table as if it were filth) You can guess what that is, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: His transfer, of course.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (grimly) Exactly. Herr Stransky is to report to Paris within a week. There's a silence in the room as if both men had forgotte the presence of Kilius. Then Brandt recovers. He turns to Kilius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please excuse me' Captain. My orderly will arrange for your billeting.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: Don't unpack too thoroughly. We'll be on the move soon.

dialogues.speaker: KILIUS
dialogues.text: (smiles) Thank you, Colonel Brandt. Se salutes, LEAVES.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: He's so new here, he didn't even ask in which direction.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: That bastard, Stransky!  (shrugs) without Steiner to contradict him, he'll get his Iron Cross and strut all over Paris. That arrogant bastard! (pause) So Stransky will be in Paris, while Steiner -- (looks glumly out the window) God knows where he is --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: stuffing food into his mouth. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show the scene as the exterior of the house, at one of th wagons. The other men are eating greedily too. Steiner turns,  looks toward the window of the house.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL'S FACE
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK to take in the Russian female priso and the old man. The women are still huddled close togeth as close to the wall as they can get. They are asleep or pretending to be asleep. The wounded woman lies with her head on another woman's lap. Her eyes are closed and she MOANS softly in her sleep.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN AND YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: They are sitting in the forefront, and are the only ones not asleep. Their heads are together and they are whispering. The girl is no more than twenty and very pretty. The old man's expression is very worried.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: as he turns from the window. He sees the old man and the young girl whispering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, you two! The old man and young girl draw slightly apart. The girl looks at Zoll and her expression is frightened.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: as he looks her figure. He looks at away, walks not to look 156. MED. The old man resumed his at the girl. His eyes glide searchingly over It is very evident what he is thinking. her quite a while, then, with an effort, turns to the door, stands with his back to it, tries at the girl.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: has moved closer to her, and has cautiously whispering. The girl's expression is still tense. She draws back in fright as Zoll suddenly comes INTO the SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: I told you to be quiet, didn't He lifts his foot and, kicking his boot against the old man's shoulder, sends him sprawling on his back. The old man looks up at him, then, as if resigned, turns over on his side. Zoll looks at the girl. It is some time before he takes his gaze away. Then, he walks to the window, looks out again. In the b.g., we SEE the men grouped around the fire, evidently eating. After a moment, Zoll turns away from the window. The CAMERA is CLOSE on his FACE and we SEE him gape and stand rooted to the spot. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to take in Zoll and the young girl. Her head is bowed and she is fingering her blouse. The top button is already open. She doesn't look at Zoll and she slowly unfastens the second button. Zoll gulps, then looks at the old man who is lying on his side, eyes close Zoll's eyes take in the rest of the room, the CAMERA PAN with his gaze. Most of the women seem to be asleep, or ar sitting with heads drooping, staring at the floor. Then, the CAMERA comes to rest on the young girl again. She is looking steadily toward Zoll who watches her in fascinati She unfastens another button. Then she closes one eye in a slow wink and smiles at Zoll.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: He holds his breath. He is perspiring slightly.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL AND GIRL
dialogues.text: The door to the hall is in the b.g. The girl has now unbuttoned the last button and is looking smilingly at Zoll, who stands hesitant. 'But now, the tread of heavy BOOTS is HEARD in the hall. Zoll hurriedly jumps to the wall and comes to an attitude of strict attention. The door opens and Schnurrbart APPEARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything all right? Zoll manages to nod indifferently. Out of the corner of his eye he looks toward the girl. She is holding her blouse closed and staring vacantly at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: As soon as Kern has finished eating he'll take over so you can eat. (his eyes rove over the prisoners) They asleep?

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (curtly) They seem to be. He is anxious for Schnurrbart to leave, but Schnurrbart takes his time. He comes all the way into the room, his  eyes on the prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (impatiently) What do you want? Everything is all right.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: Doesn't it seem funny to you that they're all asleep?

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: Why is it so funny? Schnurrbart shrugs, goes OUT. Zoll kicks the door shut quickly turns to look at the girl.

dialogues.speaker: THE GIRL
dialogues.text: She has opened her eyes and is looking encouragingly at Zoll. When he doesn't stir, she spreads her blouse open, puts her hand under her undershirt. with her other hand  she beckons to Zoll.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: He digs his teeth into his lower lip. He stands as if nailed to the spot. His eyes sweep over the heads of the other prisoners. pause upon the face of the man. Although the old man is lying with closed eyes, Zoll look at him suspiciously. But then he looks toward the girl again --

dialogues.speaker: THE GIRL
dialogues.text: She smiles at Zoll and begins to push herself along the floor toward him. This overcomes Zoll's fears. He takes one last look at the old man, then beckons to the girl with a movement of his head.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (softly)  Come. Come with me. She hesitates and glances at the old man for the briefest moment. His eyes are still closed, his back is to them.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (hoarsely, with another gesture) I said--come. The coquettish smile on the girl's face has vanished. The is fear in her eyes. She doesn't move. He takes one long stride to her, grasps her shoulders tightly, pulls her to her feet. He throws another glance at the old man who doesn't stir. Abruptly, Zoll pulls the resisting girl by the waist to the door. He throws open the door, pulls the girl into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: IN HALL
dialogues.text: looks madly around. There is a door on the opposite side of the hall. He turns to the girl, sees that she is tryi with her free hand to button her blouse. Zoll shoves her toward the opposite door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the door is flung open and Zoll, dragging the girl, COMES IN. The room is sparsely furnished, its chief feature being a huge wardrobe closet against the one wall As Zoll lays his tommy gun down in a corner, the girl suddenly breaks loose and runs toward the door. In two bounds, Zoll is at her side. He throws her to the ground, falls on her, panting with exertion and excitement. She tries to defend herself, her clenched hands battle agains his face and she begins to scream. Zoll, who has ripped her blouse off her shoulders, drags one of the blankets over her face, smothers her screams.

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: stands hesitant as he HEARS the MUFFLED SCREAMS. Then he runs to the front door, peers cautiously out, RUNS OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: have just about finished eating.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: (sitting up suddenly) What was that?

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: What was what?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: (overlapping) I thought I heard a shot.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I heard it. It was a shot, all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faint and far off) Rolf -- Kruger --

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: It's Kern! He and Kruger RUN OFF. Then the others follow.

dialogues.speaker: KERN LYING ON GROUND
dialogues.text: Anselm and Kruger run in, bend over him. Steiner and Schnurrbart COME IN.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: He's hurt -- Kern is hurt -- Steiner looks grimly in the direction of the hut.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: Maybe a company of Russians has come up.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: One shot, and it's a company of Russians! (gasping) The old Russian -- he ran past --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: What! Sorry, Steiner -- I was in no position to -- he grabbed my gun -- He falls silent, his eyes close. Steiner bends over to examine him.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: How bad is he?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (getting up)  He's probably finished. Do what you can for him. (looks grimly toward hut) I think I'll have a few words with Herr Zoll. As he starts away, the men look down worriedly at Kern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Steiner comes RUNNING IN. He is about to enter the room on the right when he HEARS WHIMPERING from within the room on the left. He listens for a moment, then the WHIMPERING IS HEARD AGAIN. Steiner lifts his foot, kicks the door in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: who is fastening the buckle on his belt, whirls around as the door flies open. The girl lies on the floor naked  and whimpering. Zoll stares incredulously at Steiner in the doorway. For a few seconds they merely stare at each other. Then Steiner comes slowly into the room and slowly approa Zoll until he is right in front of him. The WHIMPERING of the girl STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I hope you had a good time, because you're going to pay quite a price for it. He raises his gun. Zoll takes a step backward in terror.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (incredulously) You're not going to shoot me?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: You left your post, you let a  prisoner escape, you've endangered all our lives.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: But Steiner, he was asleep -- I swear it -- he was asleep. Steiner hesitates, then his eyes fall on something.

dialogues.speaker: THE SINGLE-DOORED WARDROBE
dialogues.text: It fills the entire left corner of the room. It is massively built, but has no lock, the door can only be closed by a wooden catch.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (to Zoll, indicating wardrobe) Open the door. Zoll doesn't move, his face reflecting fear. Then, invol-  untarily, he glances toward his t the farthest corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (coldly) Don't try it. You couldn't get ommy gun -- out of reach in Steiner catches his Glance. there. Come on, open the wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: Not until you tell me why you want me to open it.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (in sudden fury) Go on, go on, hurry up. Zoll turns quickly, walks to ward little.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: More. robe, opens the door a Zoll pulls the door wide open. The wardrobe is empty ins Steiner nods in satisfaction. He turns his head for a moment to see that the girl's gaze is fixed upon him. He turns to Zoll.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: If she had a gun she'd fill us both. Get into the wardrobe. Zoll, his eyes wide with fear, takes a quick step to the side. Steiner steps up to Zoll, whacks him across the face with the heavy barrel of his gun. Zoll lets out a wild shriek, presses both hands against his nose, which streams blood. Steiner, ignoring his cries, shoves him into the wardrobe. Steiner slams the door shut, pushes the wooden catch down. From within, comes Zoll's MUFFLED VOICE -- "Steiner -- Steiner --"

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (loudly) If you make a sound, I'll fire through the wood. From the side he tugs at the wardrobe until he has moved it somewhat away from the wall. Then, he squeezes between the wall and the rear of the wardrobe. He braces his back against the wail and, with a mighty shove, pushes the wardrobe over. It crashes to the floor, sending up a cloud of dust, behind which appears the girl's white face For a few seconds there is silence, then Zoll begins to SHOUT and KICK. Steiner hammers the butt of his gun against the rear wall of the wardrobe. The SHOUTING STOPS

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Stop the racket. And don't be ungrateful. For you, the war is over.  (he turns to the girl; gestures) You stay here. He looks at the wardrobe with grim satisfaction, WALKS OU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Steiner COMES OUT. He HEARS a woman SHOUTING from the other room. Steiner crosses to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Steiner COMES IN. A woman SHOUTS at him.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (looks at the wounded woman} How do you feel? Any better? The woman just stares up at him. Steiner kneels, looks at the bandage. Anselm, Kruger and Schnurrbart come RUNNING IN, in a  state of great excitement. The former has a roll of maps in his hand, the latter carries a walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: Sergeant -- we were rummaging through the second wagon and look what we --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: You picked a lovely time to go souvenir hunting. What good is a Russian walkie-talkie to us? What have you got?

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: A pretty goddamn good map. It's not only got their positions in front of Krimskaya -- it's got ours, too.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Why, that's almost German efficiency.  He spreads the map on the table, looks

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: What do you make of it?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: A work of art. What Colonel Brandt wouldn't give to have this. (looks at map again) Their Company Three is pretty well spread out. Right opposite is a hill marked on our side. (again examines map) The best spot to cross looks like Number Three's spot.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Through a whole company? at it critically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in our gorgeous gray-green uniforms, some chance we'd have.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: It's the only chance we have. The dark will give us some -- He pauses, as his eyes fall upon the Russian women. He stands silent as the men look at him. Kruger.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Tell them to undress.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Them, the women. Tell them to Then he turns to  undress.

dialogues.speaker: WARDROBE
dialogues.text: can be HEARD BANGING FEEBLY on the door.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER ROOM
dialogues.text: The men are in various stages of jonning the women's uniforms. They are grumbling.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: Where in hell is Zoll? There is a sudden silence. The men look at Steiner, who is searching around for a blouse.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I don't think we have to worry about him.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Has he skipped out?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: What would you have done in his place? Hurry up, or we'll have a Russian regiment on our necks.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: (bursting out) Suppose we do sneak through the Russian lines? Our own men will mow us down, us looking like a pack of damned Russians! A silence falls upon the men.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Don't you prefer a German bullet to a Russian one? Where's your national pride? Bitter, raucous laughter from the men.  The men, the uniforms in their arms, start for the door, with backward glances at the women. The men GO.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER AND KRUGER
dialogues.text: who are bringing up the rear. The old Russian woman SHOUTS some thing.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: She still wants to know where the young girl is.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Tell her when we're gone, to look across the hall. Kruger speaks to the woman. The wounded woman moans. Steiner, his face expressionless, bends, lifts the bandage. inspects the wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does it look?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (getting up) She's a goner. Very soon now. The wounded woman, looking up at them intently, speaks in low, halting tones. Steiner looks inquiringly at Kruger, who shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: She says how do we like it now that they have us on the run? Steiner is silent a moment.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Have you got an answer to that?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) Then, let's go. He stalks OUT, followed by Kruger.

dialogues.speaker: THE WOMEN
dialogues.text: are donning whatever clothing the men have left behind. Others have draped blankets around themselves. Three women are bending over the wounded woman. From the ex- pressions on their faces we know that the end is near for their wounded compatriot.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN AT WINDOW
dialogues.text: She is peering out cautiously. After a few moments. she turns and says something in Russian to the other women. Several come hastening to the window, look out.

dialogues.speaker: WOMEN'S POV
dialogues.text: In the b.g., we SEE the men walking off. with Steiner in  the lead, they DISAPPEAR into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: WOMEN
dialogues.text: They turn and their faces express grim satisfaction. Then, a large woman, evidently the leader, looks through the open door, across the hall to the door beyond. Her face sets. The women follow her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is lying flat on the floor. The CAMERA MOVES UP CLOSER to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is lying on his stomach, his head resting on his arms, his mouth to a small crack in the planks. After a moment, he raises himself up on one elbow, listens carefully. He thinks he hears something -- but evidently he is mistaken He lies flat on the floor again. Then he reaches for his glasses which are lying by his side. He inspects them;  they are broken. He shakes his head in anger. He presses his mouth to the crack again, breathes. The neat is intense. He wipes the Perspiration from his face. Finally he opens the buttons of his shirt, pulls down his trouser and turns over on his back. He lies still and quiet for a few moments, then an expression of great fear comes into his face. He calls out!

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: Steiner -- ! Steiner -- Kruger -- ! Schnurrbart! I'm in here -- ! There isn't a sound, and Zoll's fear grows.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: (yelling) Steiner -- do you hear me! Let me out! Schnurrbart -- it's Zoll, I'm in here -- !  His shouting has become frantic. He pounds on the door. He crooks his body and beats his heels against the bottom of the wardrobe. He digs his hands into the crack of the door and pulls until his fingers are bleeding. At last, he lies still, punting for air. Then, his expression freezes. There is the SOUND of softly advancing FOOTSTEPS The wardrobe begins to move. Twice, Zoll is jolted agains the wood -- and suddenly there is DAYLIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: are grouped around the wardrobe, the door of which has been smashed open.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL
dialogues.text: Stunned, he pulls himself up to a half-sitting position and blinks in speechless terror at the crowd of mocking faces that are bending over him, at rows of breasts bulging out of dirty underwear. Suddenly, dozens of hands reach into the wardrobe, grip his hair, his clothe his limbs, pull him up and hurl him to the floor of the room. As he starts to defend himself, his arms and legs are pinioned, his clothes torn off, and a rain of mercile blows beat down upon him. Russian CURSES fill the air.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL'S FACE
dialogues.text: as the blows rain on him. Just above him is the face of the young Russian girl he has raped. Her hair hangs in tangled strands over her forehead, her eyes gleam like green glass lighted from within. She does not strike him or curse him as the others are doing. She only stands stooped above him, staring at him in silence. And as Zoll looks into her face, the blood runs down his fore- head, bubbles out of his nose and mouth. He jerks and writhes under the kicks and punches.

dialogues.speaker: WOMEN
dialogues.text: as they beat Zoll, who is hidden from the CAMERA. Suddenly, there breaks from him a SCREAM that no longer resembles anything human. The scream paralyzes the women. For a moment, they stop the beating. Several hold their hands to their ears. Then, one woman shakes off the paralysis. with both feet at once, she jumps on the bellowing, twitching, bleeding body. The others spring on him, too, stamping, screaming and kicking.

dialogues.speaker: DOZENS OF BOOTS
dialogues.text: as they jump up and down mercilessly on Zoll's body.

dialogues.speaker: FROM HALL
dialogues.text: at the spectacle. Gradually, the kicking and jumping stop. The women turn, file slowly OUT of the room. Two of them have their arms around the softly weeping young girl. When the last have walked PAST the CAMERA, it STARTS to MOVE SLOWLY TOWARD the battered body in the  center of the room.

dialogues.speaker: ZOLL'S FEET
dialogues.text: lying quietly on the floor. A ray of SUNLIGHT is coming through the window -- and we see the feet lying in a pool of flickering LIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: dimly LIT by one candle. At the window, his back to CAMER stands a half-dressed man. Evidently, he has been roused from bed. O.S. we HEAR another man's VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: --They'll be coming through at Hill 124 at 0400. Sergeant Steiner and what's left of his platoon. Their signal will be two flares in quick succession.  then a count of four and a third flare. We are to hold our fire. The man at the window turns and we SEE that it is Captain Stransky. His lips are set tight. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal the scene as Stransky's bedroom. The man who has been speaking is Lieutenant Triebig.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (after a moment) I see. Who received this message?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Corporal Stemple.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: was there anybody with Stemple?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: No,sir. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How well do you know Stemple?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (a split second's hesitation) Very well, sir.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: He's a very good -- ah -- "friend" of yours?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (not looking at him) Yes, sir. Stransky looks at him closely.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: He knows how I feel about Sergeant  Steiner. A look passes between the two men.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Then I take it that only you, I and this Stemple know about this message.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: That's right, sir. Pause. Stransky indicates two packed bags on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: You know, of course, that I'm leaving for Paris?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Of course, sir.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (evenly)  I could arrange to have you sent for. Or would you have some objection to continuing on as my adjutant in Paris? For a moment, Triebig merely gasps.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (stammering) You don't know how grateful I would be to you for that.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (after a moment) If I sent you out on a patrol -- just four men -- two machine-gunners -- If, in the dark, you saw half a dozen men in Russian uniforms advancing on you, could anyone  blame you if you opened fire? Triebig blinks. Stransky's voice changes. It rings like steel.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Get that creature Steiner off my neck and I guarantee that you will survive this war. He must not come back even if you have to kill him with your bare hands. Triebig stands stunned, incapable of speech.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I know from reliable sources that the men in this bridgehead have been written off. Everyone south of Perekop will suffer the same fate as the sixth Army at Stalingrad.  Do you want to be here then?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (a hoarse whisper) No.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: within five days after I reach Paris, you'll have your orders to join me. You know my connections. What do you say, Triebig?

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (stares up at Stransky's flushed face, swallows hard) I -- don't know.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: You have the choice. You can rot  here in a grave, or guzzle champagne in France. Which do you prefer? Pause.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: May I know one thing?

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: What is that? Their eyes lock.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Why is it so important to you? If you are leaving here in a few hours, it shouldn't matter to you what happens to Steiner. Stransky steps over to the window to stare out into the darkness. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (in measured tones) What happens to Steiner is more important to me than whether we win or lose the war. (turns) But you will not understand that. It's my personal affair, Triebig. (pause) Are you going through with it or not? The CAMERA MOVES UP to a CLOSE SHOT of Triebig's face as he stands, indecisive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK to SHOW that he is looking at the outstretched figure of Kern who is covered by a blanket up to his chin. The SCENE is an open field. It is quite  dark. Schnurrbart comes RUNNING IN.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Do you honestly think we can slip through?

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: Well, we'd have a better chance if we didn't have to -- (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at the sleep- ing figure of Kern, lowers his voice) -- lug him along.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: What else can we do? (pause) Too bad about Kern. That's all  we needed. Suddenly the SCENE DARKENS. The men look up.

dialogues.speaker: MOON
dialogues.text: It is covered by thick clouds.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: That's the end of the moon for tonight. That's lucky anyhow. Suddenly Kern turns on his side and lets out a terrible c Kruger and Schnurrbart start. The scream continues to issue out of Kern like an endless coil of sound unwinding and unwinding from his throat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: Kern! -- Kern! -- for God's sake -- ! But the screaming continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steiner, Anselm come RUNNING IN. Steiner side.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: (anxiously) He'll have the Russians on our necks -- The screaming continues.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: (hysterically) Shoot him! Shoot him! Or it's the end of us! kneels at Kern's Steiner turns such a look of scorn upon Anselm that he subsides immediately, shame-faced.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (holding flashlight close to Kern's  face) Be quiet now -- You don't have to be afraid -- we're all with You. The screaming, which has been dwindling, bends to listen to his heart.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: If we only had a medic with us. He ought to have a shot or morphine.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (dully) He's dead. silence a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: Why be hypocrites about it? It's better for Kern and it's better for us. We couldn't get through stops. Steiner  the lines carrying him.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (enigmatically) Yes, he was good enough to die in time.

dialogues.speaker: ANSELM
dialogues.text: What do we do now, bury him?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: We haven't got the time. Let the Russians do it.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: At least we're going to have some sort of service, aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I see. You believe in God?

dialogues.speaker: SCHNURRBART
dialogues.text: At any rate, I believe we are dependent on Someone who decides our fate.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I believe in God, too, but I think He's a sadist. Pause. The men are silent.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: All right. For the sake of Schnurrbart who believes in God, and so that it shouldn't be brought up against us at the Peace Table, we'll have a service. (grimly) Gather around. They do. Steiner looks down at Kern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Kern had died at home, a few dozen, maybe even a hundred people would be standing around his grave in their best dark clothes. And they would Say, "So young, it I s always the best who go first" -- A few weeks later they would have forgotten him. Let us not forget him. And let's not feel too sorry for him. At least now, he's rid of his guilt. (pause) Cover him up -- and let's go. Steiner STRIDES OFF. The men stand a moment, then follow him OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS SEEN FROM a trench. The CAMERA MOVES UP to a MED. SHOT of Triebig and four MEN in the trench. Two machine guns have been set up. We SEE Triebig stealin a furtive look at his watch. Then he looks out over the field, his eyes trying to pierce the darkness. The CAMERA FOLLOWS his gaze, MOVES SLOWLY DOWN the field. In the b.g we begin to perceive a huddled mass. The CAMERA MOVES CLOSER and we SEE Steiner and his men, lying flat on the found. Steiner is looking at his watch. Then he looks toward Schnurrbart who raises a flare gun, FIRES TWO quic FLARES.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG AND THE FOUR MEN
dialogues.text: their FACES VISIBLE in the LIGHT o{ the FLARES. Triebig's expression is tense. He turns to the men who are manning  the machine guns.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Look sharp -- we may be getting visitors. The LIGHT from the FLARES dies away. A brief interval and the THIRD FLARE goes up. In its light, we SEE Steiner and his men running for the trench.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Russians! Fire! The two MACHINE GUNS OPEN FIRE. The SCREAMS of men mix with the RATTLE of guns. We SEE three men drop. Then the LIGHT is gone. All is darkness again.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (peering into the darkness) Steady now -- they may be coming  on again. A moment's silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: STEINER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (shouting) Sergeant Steiner here, don't shoot! Triebig's face goes white. Now, figures are SEEN running again, for the trench out of the darkness, their arms upraised.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: It's US -- Sergeant Steiner! Don't shoot! For a moment Triebig stands paralyzed, his face contorted Then, when Steiner is almost upon him, Triebig raises his tommy gun, points it at Steiner's chest.

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF TRIEBIG'S MEN
dialogues.text: (frantically)  Don't Lieutenant -- it's one of our men! Triebig, unheeding, is about to press the trigger when the man hits his arm. Triebig's GUN FIRES harmlessly into the sky. Steiner and another figure jump into the trench.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: slumped against the rear wall of the trench. He is starin wildly at Steiner who is bent over double, trying to catch his breath. His companion is also breathing heavily We SEE it is Kruger. The man who had deflected Triebig's aim addresses him. You see, Lieutenant, I was right. It's our men. Triebig, still staring at Steiner, can't answer. Now  Steiner is standing erect. He fixes a steely glance Triebig.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Why did you fire? (savagely) You got our message! Triebig finally finds his voice.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Uh--uh--what message?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: (with nervous anger) We said we were coming through in Russian uniforms -- and where and when --

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (not looking at on  anyone) I don't know anything about any -- (his voice trails off)

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: Schnurrbart sent it. He -- (looks around) Where's Schnurrbart? A silence falls as the men turn to look through the at the field. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (voice low but tight) Is Anselm there too?

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: (barely audible) darkness  He must be. (pause, puzzled) I don't get it. How could they help seeing it was us? Steiner turns to look at Triebig. Then he turns back to his men.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (voice still low) Bring them in.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: (stupidly) Who?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Who do you think? Schnurrbart and Anselm.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: But they must be dead.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I know they're dead. Bring them in. (to Triebig's men) Give them a hand. Triebig's men look to him for approval. Triebig barely nods his head, so they scramble up the trench with Kruger and DISAPPEAR INTO the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG AND STEINER
dialogues.text: as Steiner turns to face the terrified Lieutenant. Triebi waits for Steiner to speak but the Sergeant doesn't say a word. He just looks at Triebig's ashen face. For a few brief moments, Triebig tries to stand up under Steine unrelenting s tare but he cannot -- and breaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterically) It wasn't me -- I begged him -- ! But he insisted -- Steiner's face shows no surprise.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: He could have me shot, Captain Stransky! (his hysteria grows) I said to him -- what does it matter to you what happens to Steiner -- I begged him -- I -- He is practically shouting now. The men can be HEARD RUNNING back from the field. Steiner s laps Triebig hard, across the cheek, silencing him. His head is down as the men APPEAR carrying two bodies. with the help of the  other men they lower the bodies into the trench. Not a word is said. Finally the silence is broken by Kruger.

dialogues.speaker: KRUGER
dialogues.text: They're finished ail right, both of them.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Take them back to Battalion. The least we can do is bury them decently. (as the men are slow to comply) Hurry up, it'll be light soon.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: as the men set about picking up the bodies, he looks anxiously at Steiner.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: His eyes are fastened upon the two bodies. He doesn't look at Triebig.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: as they start down the trench with the two bodies. Triebi and Steiner are in the rear. As Triebig starts to follow, Steiner steps quickly to his side.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (a fierce whisper) Stay here!

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (his gun in Triebig's ribs)  Stay here! Triebig freezes.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: From Steiner's and Triebig's ANGLE, the group DISAPPEARS into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER AND TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Triebig turns terrified eyes on Steiner who is looking in the direction of the departing men. Then he turns to Triebig.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (pointing to top trench) Climb up.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Climb up!

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (quavering) You're not going to shoot me--?

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (grimly) I promise you I am not going to shoot you. Unless, of course, you don't get up there at once. Triebig casts an anxious, appealing look at Steiner who waves to the top of the trench with his gun. raises himself to the top, sits on the edge.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Stand up! Triebig stands up slowly, then turns.around.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: Steiner, I --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Turn around! (as Triebig hesitates) Turn around, or I shoot! Triebig turns. He is now a figure in the darkness. Steine reaches into his belt, takes something out -- SHOOTS OFF FLARE. The figure of Triebig is BRIGHTLY ILLUMINATED.

dialogues.speaker: TRIEBIG
dialogues.text: (screaming) Steiner -- ! But his scream is lost in the RAT - TAT - TAT of bullets the Russian side. Triebig's both hands reach into the air.
