He reels, falls heavily back into the trench. For a moment, Steiner looks down at the dark shape, the LIGHT  of the FLARE gone. Then he turns, walks quickly in the direction the men have taken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SENTRY stands guard outside. Steiner, dressed now in a rather makeshift German uniform, walks INTO the SCENE, exchanges a few words with the Sentry, ENTERS the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: are facing the door expectantly. It opens and Steiner COMES IN. Brandt greets him with an outstretched arm.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Well, well, Steiner--you're a wonder! (pumps his hand vigorously)  How you ever got through with your

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: platoon-

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (Wryly) Another man and me, Colonel. That's my platoon.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: I imagine you have a long report to make, Sergeant. You'd better have a cigarette first. He reaches for his cigarette case.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: I don't have to hear the report to know there's an Iron Cross in it for you, Steiner. (quickly)  Now, don't tell me what I can do with it. The PHONE RINGS. Brandt picks up the receiver as Kiesel lights Steiner's cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, Captain Stransky. Steiner stiffens. This is not lost on Kiesel, who snaps his lighter shut.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT ON PHONE
dialogues.text: Steiner and Kiesel in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (coldly) I'm sorry, Captain Kiesel and I will be needing my staff car almost immediately. It's only a mile and  a half to the air strip. You can walk it in twenty minutes -- Good- bye, Captain. (dryly) I hope things aren't too rough in Paris. (hangs up) I could let the bastard have the car, but to hell with him. Let him walk. (to Steiner) Well, I'm anxious to hear your story. It must be astounding.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: May I make a request, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Could I have a few hours sleep before I make the report?

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Why certainly -- even though I'm consumed with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: There's an empty room in the next house. Why don't you nap there -- and report when you're rested.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. I'll do that. He GOES. The two officers are silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: Stransky in Paris...! What I cannot understand is why this creature is the one to escape. Stransky of all people. (walks to window and looks out) Do you know what I'm looking at? Steiner running down the road like a madman.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: Which road?

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: The road to the air strip. Kiesel runs toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (sharply)  Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: I've got to stop Steiner... he'll kill Stransky.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: You will stay here. Kiesel continues to stand, indecisive, at the door. Brandt's tone becomes harder.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: I have given you an order.

dialogues.speaker: KIESEL
dialogues.text: Colonel -- you are making me guilty as an accomplice.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDT
dialogues.text: (straightening up) I am on the point of leading my  regiment into a cul-de-sac from which it has not the slightest chance of escaping. (ironically) If the whole fuhrer business were to start tomorrow, what would I most likely do? I'd close my eyes again - I'd click my heels, I'd' march, I'd heel! Germany will lose this war but Germany will survive. (puts bottle on the table) -- My last bottle of wine. Captain, will you join me in drinking to the success of Steiner's mission --  whatever it is? He starts to pour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are several small planes on the field. Several MEN are lounging about. One small plane stands on the edge of a runway. Its MOTORS are WARMING UP. The CAMERA SWINGS AWAY from the strip towards the road leading to th air strip. A tiny FIGURE is DISCERNIBLE in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: A bag in each hand, is walking toward the strip. The SOUND OF RUNNING FOOTSTEPS behind him causes him to turn. A figure is running towards him. His jaw drops as he sees it is Steiner. Steiner is now close to him. We has a Luger in his hand. The bags fall from Stransky's hands as he sees the Luger.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Steiner--!

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Clasp your hands behind the back of your head. As Stransky hesitates, Steiner makes a menacing move with the Luger. Stransky puts his hands behind his head.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Are you aware of what you are doing? You're dealing with an officer --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I think that for the time being, we can forget about the differences in our rank -- and class.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: Steiner -- you'll hang for this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're planning, but you'll never get away with it. This is a heavily traveled road.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: In that case, I'll be quick. For a long time, Captain Stransky, I haven't had anything to live for -- for a long time -- but the Russians couldn't do it, disease couldn't kill me? poor Lieutenant Triebig couldn't do it. Not even you could manage it  (moves closer to Stransky) And not wanting to live, yet not willing to die, do you know what that kind of a conflict does to a man? (laughs in Stransky's face) Now, in a crazy sort of way I am grateful to you, Captain Stransky. Thanks to you, I am willing to die. I could shoot you and then the Army would hang me. But, no, that isn't good enough.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (his dignity going,  his voice rising) Are you out of your mind? Steiner, if you'll just think for a moment --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: I did think, Captain Stransky. I thought and thought -- and did nothing!

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (whimpering now) Steiner -- Steiner -- you're mad -- you're absolutely mad! Steiner steps close to Stransky. With his free hand, he pulls a grenade from his belt.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Stand close to me, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (backing away) No -- No -- You can't --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: (pulls Stransky to him) This will do for the both of us -- the final fraternization --

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (a whimper so low it can scarcely be heard) Steiner -- please -- Steiner -- Steiner pulls the pin from the grenade, holds himself and Stransky.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: What's the count before it goes it between  off?

dialogues.speaker: STRANSKY
dialogues.text: (his lips move, but no sound comes out) -- Steiner --

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Count with me, Captain -- One -- Two -- The CAMERA STARTS to MOVE UP and AWAY from Steiner and Stransky.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: -- Three -- Four -- Five -- Six -- The CAMERA is at TREE TOP LEVEL now -- Suddenly there is a SHATTERING REPORT. The branches of the tree tremble. The CAMERA STAYS on the tree for a moment. The leaves stop trembling. There is a vast silence now. The CAMERA  starts to PULL AWAY AGAIN. As it DOES:
